TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Maralinga rehabilitation project, SA.

SPEECH.PARA: The Maralinga and Emu sites are located in South Australia in the region north of the Nullarbor Plain. Maralinga is 270 kilometres north-west of Ceduna. Emu is 190 kilometres north-east of Maralinga. Between 1953 and 1963, Great Britain conducted several programs of nuclear warhead development trials at Maralinga and Emu. These included detonations of nine nuclear weapons and hundreds of `minor trials' that dispersed radioactive materials. The former test site areas are contaminated to various levels with plutonium and other artificially produced radioisotopes that present an unacceptable risk to future users of the sites.

PARA.TAB: During 1990, the Commonwealth government agreed on a preferred rehabilitation option for the Maralinga test sites as a basis for seeking a substantial contribution to rehabilitation works from the British government. It is intended that upon completion of the project the test site area will be returned to South Australian control for addition to the Maralinga Tjarutja freehold lands.

The proposed clean-up will reduce the radiological hazards of the test site to enable Aboriginal use and transit of the test site area, reduce and possibly eliminate the need for control and surveillance of the sites, and remove potential Commonwealth liabilities arising from site contamination.

The Public Works Committee tabled its report on 20 June 1995, recommending the project at an estimated cost of $104.4 million at November 1994 prices. In its report, the committee recommended that an independent audit of the trials and the results of the in situ vitrification of material containing plutonium be undertaken by competent experts not associated with the project. If the results of the review indicate that the in situ vitrification process provides encapsulation and mixing of material to prescribed standards, the process can be extended to full-scale treatment of the burial pits at Taranaki. If the results of the in situ vitrification trials are inconclusive or do not provide results to prescribed standards, the further direction of the project should be reviewed.

In response to these recommendations, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has advised that a cautious step-wise approach has been adopted to the assessment of the applicability of the in situ vitrification technology to stabilisation of plutonium contaminated debris pits at the Taranaki site.

In accordance with the Public Works Committee's recommendations, results of field trials of this technology will be assessed by independent experts. These experts will report through the Australian Radiation Laboratory, the project regulator. Methodology for the alternative process of controlled exhumation and reburial of the pits at Taranaki is being developed in case the results of the in situ vitrification trials do not confirm that application of this technology at Taranaki is practicable and effective.
If approved, work will commence in mid-1995, with completion scheduled for late 1999. I thank the committee for its report. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Mr Snowdon:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise in the House to support the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. The EMDG scheme has been spectacularly successful in encouraging and assisting Australian firms, particularly small and medium firms, to enter the export ring. I am very pleased that the government's commitment in Working Nation to extend the life of this scheme for another four years has been brought to fruition in this legislation now before the House.

PARA.TAB: As a general proposition, the measures contained in this bill are designed primarily to improve the focus of the export market development grants scheme. That focus will increasingly come on to small and medium sized firms. These firms are the ones which various studies have indicated offer the best opportunity for export growth for Australia. I am pleased to say that many of those small and medium sized firms referred to in the McKinsey report and others are located in the electorate of Corio, which encompasses the Geelong region.

These measures will have budgetary ramifications. They will better target the grant assistance available under the scheme and also contain the costs of the scheme. In the past, schemes such as this have had a somewhat chequered history. There has always been considerable debate in the business community, and within the bowels of government, about their effectiveness in stimulating exports. Many schemes in the past have been typified by runaway costs, budget blow-outs and widespread rorting by elements of the business sector.

Those responsible elements in the business sector have, of course, not been engaged in that practice. But it has been a sad feature of previous schemes that these practices have been allowed to occur and that the subsequent costs of the schemes have been quite substantial. It has taken a Labor government to refine this excellent scheme to a point where it is specifically targeted and where Australian taxpayers get the maximum result from the dollars that they are expending on it.

Opposition speakers who have preceded me in this debate have made great play of Australia's export performance and they have outlined how they view that performance. I will take up later on in the debate some of the specific points that they made. I think it is important to understand that over the last decade there has been fundamental restructuring of the Australian economy. This government has pursued a comprehensive package of micro-economic reform, and the labour retraining programs that this government has instituted through Working Nation—programs that lead the Western world—have had spectacular success in improving the productivity and competitiveness of Australian enterprises.

That has been manifest in many reports that indicate the extent of export growth in Australia. One report brought down in late 1993 indicated that of the 32 economies that had recorded quite significant export growth since the mid-1980s, Australia recorded the fastest growth in elaborately transformed manufactures of any economy in the OECD. This was not an OECD report. It was a report containing a commentary on this situation.

I think that report highlights the fact that Australia's export performance has been spectacular over the past decade. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) drew to the attention of the House in question time the other day the fact that Australia's international competitiveness had improved by some 40 per cent since 1983. You do not achieve that success overnight. It has been the leadership of this government in relation to economic policy that has resulted in substantial benefits in the economic area.

I see that the opposition member at the dispatch box, the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), is smiling. How he wishes that the coalition could emulate the record of this government in relation to export performance, growth, low inflation and low industrial disputations. Let us not go over the old ground because when we make those comparisons the opposition gets a little embarrassed.

The improvement in Australia's international competitiveness has not occurred overnight. As I said, the leadership of the government and the scheme we are debating today have been critical factors in the improvement of our export performance. When we look at our economic policies, which have given great stimulus to exports in this country, we see that it is this government, like no other before it, that has broken the back of inflation. The fact that we have achieved such record low inflation in this country has put us in the best competitive position to give even greater stimulus to those exports.

As I have mentioned, the government has also pursued a comprehensive program of micro-economic reform in the transport area and in financial markets. In this country we have seen massive tariff reform in key industries such as the textile, clothing and footwear industries and the passenger motor vehicle industry. Much criticism has been levelled at the government for the policies that it has pursued in these areas in the past. I must say that in my electorate some 4,000 to 5,000 jobs disappeared in those two industries by virtue of very courageous decisions that were taken by this government. But those policies are starting to bear fruit. For example, in the textile industry in Geelong we have seen substantial expansion. We are on the verge of quite massive reinvestments in new technologies and new long-term job opportunities that will be achieved as a result of our low inflation figures.

What this government has been able to achieve through its labour market reforms, which have been undertaken without the social dislocation that has occurred in societies that have been run by conservative governments around the world in the last decade, has been unparalleled in the Western world. The government has also pursued a wide range of investment incentives. All of these things have served to lift the productivity of the manufacturing sector in particular and the economy in general. That lift in productivity has enabled Australian firms to contain costs and to become more competitive in the international environment.

That competitiveness has been encouraged very much by the export market development grants scheme which we are debating today. The scheme has been very critical in ensuring that exporters, especially the small and medium firms who have sought to enter the international trading arena on the back of new competitiveness that the Australian economy has achieved, receive support.

I would like to draw the attention of the House to some of the statistics regarding Australia's export performance over the last 10 years. Our total exports have increased by 6.3 per cent in nominal terms to some $64.6 billion in 1993-94. Over the past decade we have seen very strong growth in manufactured exports of about 16 per cent per annum. That is a revolution in Australia's export performance. But, when we go deeper into the statistics, we see that in the last five years, as far as elaborately transformed manufactures are concerned, their share of total exports has increased from 15 per cent to over 21 per cent and last year their growth was in the region of 14 per cent.

We need to examine not only the growth but also the diversity that has been achieved in the sorts of elaborately transformed manufactures that are now being exported. I am pleased to say that the outlook for our exports appears to be very sound. We have observed some contractions in the world economies, particularly the motor economies of Japan and the United States. But I think the overall assessment is that we will avoid the recessions that have bedevilled the international economic cycle in the past.

Over the last 10 years this country has developed a revolution in the export culture. The government has introduced a competition policy on the back of the Hilmer report and, while I might not agree with every particular measure the government has brought down in that competition policy, nevertheless in key critical areas the competitive instincts of Australian enterprise, both public and private, will be strengthened by some of those reforms.

Looking at the nature of the recent record levels of investment that have taken place in the Australian economy, we see that this particular investment is in future productive capacity. We will have the capacity over the next decade to meet world demand as well as domestic demand. The initiative of the new accord struck between the government and the ACTU, which was announced recently by the Prime Minister, will lock in not only the low inflation which is so critical to Australia's economic performance, but also some very real benefits to Australian households and Australian workers. Looking at the parameters of the total mix and scenario, I think any reasonable person would be optimistic about Australia's future, especially when noting our recent history and the magnificent strides which we have made in the export area.

Five of the amendments to the act represent substantial changes to the scheme in the wake of the Working Nation statement. Many of the amendments that are being proposed are more of a technical nature and either clarify or refine existing provisions or expand them.

The first major amendment I would like to deal with in this debate today is that relating to the life of the current scheme, which has been extended to the grant year 1998-99. That was a commitment we gave in Working Nation, and that is a promise that is being fulfilled by this government.

We hear a lot from the other side about the broken promises of government. We cannot really levy that charge at the opposition because we have not really seen the colour of its ink, as far as policy goes. This is one of the hundreds of commitments that the government had already met when it came into office in 1993 and when it brought down the Working Nation statement in 1994. Evaluation of the export market development grants scheme indicates that there is a return of some $25 for every one dollar spent on this scheme, and I think it makes good sense to continue it.

Another major amendment to the bill relates to access to the scheme by single-service tourism providers. I see the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) waiting in the wings. I am sure he will take this matter up. We know of his very intense interest in the tourism industry and, no doubt, he will have some very interesting things to say about this particular provision.

This amendment recognises the enormous contribution made to the Australian economy by tourism. Provisions of the scheme are usually not made available to the service sector, unless they are declared in the regulations. With regard to this situation at the moment, for tourism services to be `eligible tourism services' under the act and regulations, three services must be provided—passenger land transport, water transport, air transport, accommodation, admissions to tourist attractions or the provision of tour escort facilities.

The bill provides for the scheme to be extended to include the provision of single tourism amenities referred to as designated tourism services. The bill outlines the mechanics of assessing the benefits that might accrue to single-service tourism operators. The bill also allows the tourism industry access to the approved joint venture and consortium facility that operates under this particular scheme.

I am very pleased that the government has opened up the scheme even further to Australia's tourism industry. It is Australia's biggest export earner. Looking at some of the statistics of this particular industry, some six per cent of GDP is earned or produced through this particular sector, and over six per cent of the work force is employed in it.

Tourism is very important to many regional economies. That is why the government has recognised that potential in the scheme and has also recognised that potential in the budget. For example, some $80 million has been made available through the Australian Tourist Commission for overseas promotion. We are continuing to fund the Department of Tourism. Some $5.2 million has been made available for the regional tourism development program.

I am pleased to say that my electorate received the largest grant, I think, in Australia to finance a tourist information facility that will serve as the gateway to the Great Ocean Road and the great hinterland of the Western District in Victoria. We are providing $1.3 million for tourism research, $3.4 million for national ecotourism and $762 million for Sydney West airport, which will service the Sydney Olympic Games.

This particular scheme and the provisions of the scheme relating to the tourism industry have come under some heavy criticism from those on the opposition benches. I listened with interest to the words of the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) in the House yesterday when he severely criticised the government for not going further down the road of opening up this particular scheme to tourism operators.

I do not doubt the sincerity of the interest of the honourable member for La Trobe. I served on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology with him. That committee produced a report which made some very specific recommendations about the access of the tourism industry to the EMDG scheme. However, I think he is being a little too critical of the government on this occasion.

We have made a very strong commitment in this bill before the House to retain this scheme and open it up even further, not only to the small tourist operators but also to the small and medium firms, which I know is of great interest to the member for La Trobe. We have certainly broadened the access of tourist operators to this scheme.

Obviously, some people will argue that the government has not gone far enough in this regard, but I would ask them to keep in mind that this government operates under fiscal constraints, budgetary constraints, which have dictated that every proposal that has come up in the last budget must be subject to significant scrutiny. That scrutiny, when it is taken in its totality, has led to a budget surplus and a downward pressure on interest rates which obviously is of great benefit not only to the tourist industry but to small and medium firms elsewhere.

I want to take issue with the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), who got up in this place and levied some very heavy criticism at the government's export performance. I really cannot understand the honourable member for Maranoa and many of the people opposite who continually run down Australia. It is bad enough that many of them cannot even countenance that Australia ought to have an Australian head of state. But when they really go and run down the nation's great export performance then I think it is legitimate to take issue with them.

The member for Maranoa mentioned the New Zealand economy. What he failed to say is that the New Zealand economy has basically gone back to the level that it was at in 1984. There are several hundred thousand New Zealanders working in Australia. I simply put the proposition: if it is so good in New Zealand, why are they over here? Indeed, if it is so good in New Zealand, why don't some of the members opposite go and live there? They want to run down this country. They want to run down the export performance of this nation. They cannot even countenance an Australian head of state, yet they get up in this House day in and day out and run down the Australian economy and the Australian work force. I commend this bill to the House because it gives very strong support to a significant sector of the Australian economy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —While I welcome the comments made by the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) regarding the extension of the export market development grants to the tourist industry, may I just say to him that one of the reasons I am intervening in this debate on the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill is that what we have before the House at the moment is an amended bill. This bill has come back from the Senate with some amendments that have vastly improved the legislation. It has specifically singled out the tourist industry as one industry that should receive even more consideration from the present government.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's amendments in the Senate raised the benefit amount that would be available to tourist operators to the full 50c in the dollar and also allowed for establishment of joint ventures within the tourist industry to be part of this particular scheme. It absolutely amazes me that the government could have come into this place with its original bill in light of the fact that we have already had two joint parliamentary committees, including members of the government's own political party, which have recommended that the tourist industry get full consideration. Yet when we saw the original bill, we noted that the tourist industry had this discrimination placed upon it.

It brings me back to the original concept of the EMDG: that is, when it did apply to the tourist industry in those heady early days of the 1980s, the industry had full access to the EMDG until 1985. You might remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, that after 1985 the government brought in what I believe was probably an ill-advised TOPS scheme. There were all sorts of troubles with that scheme. It floated off. Then we had the regeneration of EMDG which applied only to what could almost be described as `the club' in terms of the inbound tourist industry. The fight has gone on from there.

Two joint committees of this place have recommended that the tourist industry get full consideration—and well it should. As the member for Corio has already said, the tourist industry is our biggest foreign exchange earner and our biggest private sector employer in Australia. The potential of the industry is quoted time and time again by the government. But the reality is that until such time as it does receive equitable treatment it may never reach its full potential.

I was absolutely horrified to read the words of Senator McMullan in the other place when he was replying to the debate on the bill. His basic argument was that the tourist industry is getting plenty of consideration and plenty of funding—the member for Corio also mentioned that the industry will receive $80 million this year—and that will just about do it. This really highlights the complete lack of understanding this government has, and many bureaucrats have, of the way in which the tourist industry operates. I suppose if you asked members of the bureaucracy and a number of the ministers in this particular government, `Who is the tourist industry?', they would probably tell you that it is Qantas, Ansett, Hilton hotels and the Sheraton group. That is about as far as their vision goes.

The reality of the tourist industry is that 92 per cent of its composition consists of small businesses. Mums and dads are the backbone of the tourist industry in Australia. They are not the leeches of the industry; they are the entrepreneurs of the industry. They are the people who give the attractions to those who wish to visit Australia.

If we look at the development of the tourist industry over the last 20 years, we see that there have been some amazing success stories. I remember that during my time at the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation in 1983 and 1984 we worked very hard to get Australian tourism promoted overseas. It was important to give a promotional campaign on Australia as a whole or on a state as a whole, but the reality is that we were absolutely dependent on the tourist operators in the regions to come with us to provide that promotion so that we had a few hooks with which to bring people to Australia.

Quite frankly, we have a very competitive world. The vision of Australian tourism in those early days was the reef, the rock and the Sydney Harbour Bridge—and they were big attractions. But we have developed the industry a lot further than that. The tremendous inflow of tourists we now have is purely because we have other infrastructures and operators in place. Those operators have helped to open up many regions of Australia to ensure that we get the maximum benefit from the flow of international visitors coming to Australia.

One of the great success stories of those early days was an operator out of Port Douglas in Far North Queensland called the Quicksilver Connection. It was a family business, and that family poured everything it had into a catamaran that ran out to the Great Barrier Reef and provided one of the most incredible diving experiences that could be had anywhere in the world.

I know that the family involved in the Quicksilver Connection was very dependent on the export market development grants scheme. If it had not been for EMDG, they probably would never have got there. I have been involved in a couple of the major international trade shows such as ITB in Berlin or JTB in Tokyo and I know that, without the assistance of EMDG, it is very doubtful whether an operation such as Quicksilver Connection would ever have got off the ground.

What do we now have out of Cairns? Quicksilver Connection has been bought out by a major international operator and now has a fleet of about five boats, and there are also three or four other operators in the same business. It has been one of the greatest attractions that the Far North Queensland area has had for international visitors. There are dozens of stories like that all around Australia and in the far-flung parts of Australia.

One of the great challenges the tourist industry now has is that, while we have made this tremendous initial impact, we have to keep going if we are going to not only maintain the numbers but increase the numbers. With the changing nature of tourism in Australia there are some enormous opportunities to open up new districts and new areas. My friend the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who is at the table, will tell you that probably the next great area of Australia to open up to international visitors will be the north-west of Western Australia.

In terms of natural attractions, there are probably very few other places in the world that are as spectacular as this part of Western Australia. There is very little infrastructure there at all, but the infrastructure is starting to come in. It is not coming in with the Sheratons and the Hiltons of this world; it is coming in with small operators, small investors, people who know how to innovate and people who know how to sell. But, as so often happens, they are restricted in their capital and, if you are going to play in an international market, you need some big dollars.

The principle the government has in the Australian Tourist Commission's promotion is right. The Australian Tourist Commission operates as an umbrella over the entire industry. Its sole purpose in life is to attract people to Australia. It does it as an umbrella operation; it does not single out a particular area necessarily. It certainly does not single out a particular business. That is done by the individual operators themselves or in consortia through the Inbound Tourism Organisation of Australia, and that is the way it should be. As I said, the real innovators in this industry are the small business operators. They are 92 per cent of the business and they are the people that the opposition's amendments are designed to help and designed to get overseas so that they can promote Australia.

The other thing the government does not realise is that there is a changing nature in tourism. It is happening virtually every day of the week. There is some aspect of the industry that has to be updated and there is some new attraction that can come on line. If you look at an analysis of what has happened in the tourist industry in Australia in the last 15 years, you would see how our industry has progressed. Initially, we were looking for bulk tourism. I suppose to be more definitive, we were looking for Japanese tourists. Yes, they came in their numbers and they centred themselves to a very great extent on Sydney and the Gold Coast. There was nothing wrong with that. It was one way of getting the industry opened up.

The second wave was to go into North America, after Crocodile Dundee. That worked too. Those tourists were probably a little bit more adventurous because it was at that time that Far North Queensland came on line. Then this thing that the government has just discovered, ecotourism, came into being. Ecotourism was a major attraction from about 1984 or 1985. It was the small operators who realised the potential of that, who went overseas on these delegations, who went to these trade shows, who spent their money and who made that investment to get those things starting to happen and to come off. We know the success story of that.

We are going through another phase at the moment, that of the independent traveller, more euphemistically called the backpacker. Fifteen years ago if you asked people what the definition of a backpacker was they would tell you it was somebody who came into Australia with a clean T-shirt and a $10 note in his or her pocket and while here changed neither. The backpacker now is the biggest spender in the tourist industry. The average backpacker is worth about $5,500 a head while in Australia. Backpackers are not staying at the Sheratons or the Hiltons; they might spend a day or two having a look around a capital city but the reality is that they are going out into the far-flung parts of Australia. They are going out and spending their money in a direct sense in many of the regional communities of Australia and they are helping local economies and creating local employment. Backpackers are not going near the big operators; they are going to the small, innovative operators, the people we are trying to make sure get the full benefit of the export market development grants through the amendments in this bill.

I hope that at least in the House of Representatives, when the vote is finally taken on this, there is going to be a realisation of just what our amendments mean in terms of the future of the tourist industry and a realisation of the absolutely essential nature of these amendments to make sure that we continue to grow and that the small operators—the innovators of the industry—have the capacity to get overseas and to promote.

It does cost a lot of money to go overseas and promote. If you look at the $80 million that the Australian Tourist Commission has been allocated this year, you can see why that sort of money is required. You can see what is going to be spent on television campaigns in places like Japan, where one television ad can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars for a minute, or in the United States; and you can see the difficulty that the Australian Tourist Commission might have in promoting around Europe, because of the diversity of language and the diversity of the media there.

That is fine. That is what the ATC is all about. But it is very much going to be up to the little operators within the industry to go out and really sell the sizzle that is the Australian tourist industry. My recommendation to government members opposite would be to please accept these amendments. They are equitable, they are a good investment in Australia, they are a good investment in export income for us, and, most importantly, they are a magnificent investment in jobs for young Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Market Development Grants Amendment (No. 2) Bill arose out of policies announced by the government in the Working Nation white paper more than 12 months ago. At that time the government confirmed its commitment to place a high priority on facilitating export growth by equipping Australian firms with an excellent export market intelligence network providing targeted financial assistance to new exporters and by promoting the growing export culture across Australian industry.

PARA.TAB: That statement of policy, of course, underscores this legislation and the government's continuing support for the export market development grants scheme. In the Working Nation white paper, the government further announced that the effectiveness of export programs for small and medium sized exporters, which often have significant cash flow and financial constraints at the early stages of exporting, would be extended by several provisions, and these feature in this legislation.

The first change is to expand the export market development grants scheme to provide export marketing assistance to single-service tourism operators. This recognises the significance of the tourism industry to export growth. Those matters were addressed quite capably, as is his style on tourism issues, by the member for Fadden (Mr Jull). The second is to examine the extension of the scheme to other key service sector exporters in the course of 1994-95 in the light of the findings of the LEK services study.

The third provision—and it is reflected in this legislation—is to continue the scheme for a further five years, thereby providing assistance to approximately 5,000 exporters a year at a cost of $231 million in 1994-95. That would increase to just under $300 million by the 1997-98 financial year. The fourth change announced in Working Nation was to assist offshore marketing activities by providing low interest loans through the international trade enhancement scheme for a further four years at $50 million per annum.

Most of those provisions are reflected in this legislation. So the bill is acting on the policies announced in the Working Nation white paper. It is also consistent with the government's non-interventionist approach to industry policy. Non-interventionist approaches recognise the futility of industry or sector planning in an economic environment which features rapid movements in capital, dynamic shifts in competitiveness and trade capacity across advanced economies and rapid changes in technology. Much of the technology, particularly in the information area, has moved outside national boundaries and challenges governments to find appropriate forms of national regulation.

The non-interventionist approach recognises that with rapid changes in capital movements, shifts in trading capacity and changes in technology it is not possible for a government to plan ahead for a period of, for example, five years in the medium term and expect that its planning assumptions would hold true throughout that period. In a dynamic economy it is rather futile for governments to embrace and endorse a style of interventionist sector planning for industry. Rather, there is a need for government to adapt to a rapidly changing economic environment by developing rapid response policy instruments.

In recent years, we have seen the growing redundancy of slow response policy instruments not only in Australia but also in most advanced economies. It is this approach towards the legitimate tools of government in industry policy, a preference for rapid response policy instruments to cope with the rapidly changing economic environment, that underscores the federal government's industry policy and trade strategy.

The need to have a rapid response to clearing blockages to market entry, in the information available to new market entrants or in developing exporters, to clear blockages in the availability of capital for new industries, new companies and a new and emerging export potential in Australia, features in this legislation. The policy and framework for industry policy is about rapid responses, to enable firms—those firms that are not born globally but rather born locally—to develop the critical mass needed in their information, capital capacity, training capacity and research and development capacity to develop their competitiveness and move from trading in the domestic market to trading in overseas markets and improving Australia's export performance.

These areas are underscored by the government's active commitment to micro reform to make the economy more efficient, to lower the cost of doing business, to lower the cost of business inputs and create the sort of flexible environment in which businesses would best conduct their trade. This is the approach the government has adopted—to rely on rapid response policy instruments and to have trade and industry policies in place which encourage locally born firms to develop the critical mass needed to trade effectively overseas. The government underscores that with a very effective set of micro reform policies which lower the costs of doing business.

I draw the attention of the House to the Working Nation white paper. Page 51 provides a very useful statement of the government's philosophy—this non-interventionist approach—and the sort of economic and trading environment with which we are seeking to deal. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Firms today operate in a radically different environment to that of 20 years ago. At the broadest industry level, modern telecommunications and transport systems have revolutionised the mechanisms for doing business, and have internationalised markets as diverse as finance and horticulture . . .

Product lives are shorter and goods and services are more elaborate, skill intensive and customer specific . . . Innovation, encompassing all business activities from research and development, to marketing, management and industrial relations, has become critical. The successful players are flexible and innovative, increasingly small and medium enterprises (SMEs), operating against a backdrop in which competition is intense and capital highly mobile.

The most successful firms worldwide are those that have adopted a long term view in developing their business strategies. Their focus is on continual improvement and the need to develop new processes, products, skills and markets in response to rapidly changing patterns of demand and heightened competition. Attention to skill formation, customer requirements and investment in new equipment, knowledge and processes—the dynamics of economic growth—is the key to their success.

That was an outstanding statement and shows the government's approach to industry policy with the development of an export based culture of economic activity throughout the country. That is one of the main features of the export market development grants scheme, which is the subject of this legislation. It is apparent that any government support which is used by industry as a de facto subsidy and which industry comes to rely on would be a counterproductive practice.

PARA.TAB: In schemes such as this, the government needs to strike a balance—a balance between encouraging industry to upgrade, become more innovative and develop skills, training, export capacity and research and development without using government support and subsidies as a source of reliance, which would result in the underpinning of profit margins. Any business or economy which relies on subsidies would find that this dulls innovation, negates the need to upgrade, negates skill development and diminishes the continuous improvement model that underscores economic success in the 1990s.

This government needs to find the balance and have effective performance measures in place that provide a guide to whether or not the grants are being used effectively. The subsidies might become counterproductive and form a de facto system of reliance and dependence, and industry may lose the very important incentives to innovate and upgrade.

My interest on the subject of the correct balance between innovation and reliance arose from a question I placed on the Notice Paper—question No. 2320 directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade (Mr Bilney)—in relation to the export market development grants scheme. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What are the details of export development grants paid by Austrade to companies in the: (a) clothing, textile and footwear, (b) automobile, (c) music, and (d) shipping industries, in (i) 1992-93, (ii) 1993-94, and (iii) 1994-95.

That is, for the last three financial years. My interest in this stems from the fact that each of those four industry groups in Australia are heavily import protected by international standards. The answer to that question—which appeared in the Hansard on Tuesday 20 June—should be of great interest to the House. It showed that protected industries in Australia are substantial recipients of export development grants. In 1993-94 the textile, clothing and footwear industry received 111 grants to the value of more than $6 million; the automobile industry received 64 grants to the value of more than $4 million; the music industry received 11 grants to the value of about half a million dollars; and the shipping industry received 16 grants to the value of $850,000.

PARA.TAB: In 1993-94 the aggregate of those four industries was 3,277 grants at a value of $195 million, which represented 6.2 per cent of all the grants that were awarded under the export development grants scheme and six per cent of the value of those grants. This reinforces the point that the export development grant scheme should be used as a performance measure by which the government can gauge the success of its import protection policies. It also raises the issue that these industries are competitive enough to enter overseas markets—that is why they are receiving grants—yet overseas firms, under other aspects of government policy, are restricted from entering Australian markets.

In the vernacular, that would be regarded as `good work if you can get it': a business is import protected on one part of the market but receives export development grants for its overseas efforts. Some of these industries and companies are burning the candle at both ends. They are import protected and receiving what amounts to a consumer subsidy because of the tariffs, yet they are also export subsidised. This further reinforces the point that industry protection works to protect capital and profits, not necessarily jobs.

It also reinforces the point that industry protection is a fairly blunt instrument because obviously among the TCF, automobile, music and shipping industries some internationally competitive firms are taking advantage of the export market development grants scheme. They are competitive, but there must be laggards in their industry that demand some level of import protection. So import protection, by its very nature, is insensitive to the diversity and various levels of competitiveness that would be apparent in any industry at any one time.

The government should use this information and this scheme as a means of measuring the performance and effectiveness of its import protection policies. There may be an argument to say that, if firms are competitive enough to export—that is, their international competitiveness is high—they do not require a high level of import protection at the other end of the market.

I also note that the government has placed the export market development grants scheme under scrutiny and there has been a performance assessment of the scheme. The major amendments proposed by this bill give effect to the recommendation of the 1994 evaluation of the scheme entitled Helping to meet the export challenge. The key findings and recommendations of the evaluation were that the scheme is achieving its objective of encouraging firms to seek out and develop export markets; revenues from taxes on grant receipts and profits on additional exports were estimated to return 42 per cent of the cost of the scheme to the Commonwealth, so there is a good element of cost recovery in this scheme; most of the growth in the scheme has come from the services sector, and that is acknowledged in this bill by extending the grants to the tourism industry—a very important part of the Australian services sector; the minimum level of qualifying expenditure, the grant rate, number of grants and performance tests were judged to be largely appropriate; the number of firms claiming grants and then dropping out of the scheme is not ideal; the scheme should be extended to all claimants in the tourism sector; and the scheme should be extended for another five years.

In general, based on the performance appraisal entitled Helping to meet the export challenge, the government and the House can be confident this scheme is working well, which is my point. I come back to the answer provided by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) that the scheme is working well and that certain companies may not require the import protection they have been afforded in the past and are scheduled to receive in the future.

Tariff reduction programs combined with export enhancement grants schemes such as this have a very important and beneficial effect on industry. For instance, between 1991 and 1994 the average effective assistance from protection to producers of motor vehicles and parts was reduced from 48 per cent to 38 per cent. Producers noted that by the year 2001 the rate will be down to 19 per cent.

Car manufacturing companies have responded by instituting major improvements in productivity, with the result that the time taken to build a car at assembly plants has fallen by about one-third since 1990—that is, from 52.5 hours in 1990 to just 34.5 hours in 1993. Productivity gains were an outstanding 31 per cent for 1992 and 1993 alone. The quality of Australian cars has also improved. The best Australian cars had in 1993 achieved quality levels better than some imported Japanese vehicles, as measured by owner identified faults.

Again in relation to the performance measure on improved productivity and competitiveness, those same automobile manufacturers are receiving for 1994-95—the current financial year, which is not yet complete—50 grants under the export market development grants scheme to a value of $2 million. Tariff reductions and export enhancement for the textile, clothing and footwear industries have also produced massive improvements in productivity and competitiveness.
I note the trade minister, in his own magazine which is aptly named trade blazer, reflected on the success of the textile industry in generating export revenue. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1994, the textile industry generated more than $400 million in export revenue, almost triple the level of just six years earlier.
The minister went on to state:

It is particularly encouraging to see export growth in one of Australia's sophisticated manufacturing industries—in this case using the latest in technology and management skills to add value to high quality Australian fibres.

Again, this is a good measure of the success of the export enhancement scheme and also how lower import protection is a very strong incentive for industry to become more competitive and more productive. Some of these arguments could be used by the government to revise its schedule for the phased reduction in tariffs on manufactured goods, especially in light of these export performance levels.

PARA.TAB: Further, it is true to say that in recent decades the only advances in economic thought and analysis have been by empiricists—those willing to use the methods of observation and experience in their assessment of economic institutions, technology and culture. These studies are focused on an understanding of the tools of national competitiveness in an international trading environment.

I refer the House to the work of Michael Porter, Robert Reich and Paul Romer—Romer being one of the new growth theorists producing some outstanding work in the United States. In relation to export enhancement, their work shows that nations succeed in certain industries because the corporate environment is dynamic and challenging, pressuring firms to build and widen their advantages over time.

The competitive advantage of nations comes from industrial upgrading and continuous improvement. New investment, technology, knowledge and skills give companies a competitive edge on world markets. This again confirms the basis of an export culture in Australia. The basis is to bring the tools of competitiveness close to firms and recognise that sector planning and grossly interventionist industry policies in a dynamic economy are essentially futile, and, further, that government interventions, where needed, should be based on rapid response instruments which help firms in capital formation, training, skill development and the critical mass needed to jump from domestic to export markets.

The basis of an export culture is to bring the tools of competitiveness close to the enterprise—that is, to make sure that each enterprise in Australia, as it eyes off international markets, has the industrial relations capacity, the training and the research and development within its own hands to upgrade its level of productivity and competitiveness and penetrate export markets effectively.

In most areas the government has the agenda right. In some aspects of training and management, reflecting on the findings of the recent Karpin report, more needs to be done. Continuous reform is necessary to bring the tools of competitiveness within the reach of every enterprise in Australia, particularly those with export potential.

On top of that, and in conclusion, this is a good scheme enhanced by the legislation, consistent with the government's correct philosophy and approach to industry policy. I look forward to further measures by the trade and industry minister to build on these achievements and make the Australian economy even more effective in export performance and even more internationally competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite sure that the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) is absolutely right when he says that more does need to be done. There is a great need for more reform, particularly in relation to Australia's export performance as we anticipate what on Friday will probably bring another record high current account deficit. To the extent that we are talking about export enhancement in this debate, I do not disagree with a lot the member said but I do strongly agree with him that much more needs to be done and can be done, but in fact has not been done, by this government.

PARA.TAB: Every day we point out the government's deficiencies. Its industrial relations policy is just one area where so much could be achieved in terms of improving Australia's international competitiveness but shows how little this government has been able to do because it is hamstrung by its relationship with the trade union movement.

This is not so much a debate about economics—though I agree with most of the member's economics. Very clearly the issue in this debate is equity, not economics. We on this side of the House would like to hear from government speakers—perhaps the member for Reid (Mr Ferguson), who will follow me in this debate, will enlighten us—why the government is, by virtue of this legislation, discriminating against the tourism industry.

We have moved and had carried in the Senate amendments to this legislation which will provide equal treatment for the tourism industry as far as the EMDG scheme is concerned. This legislation quite simply and blatantly—and I assume for the purpose of saving what would amount to a very small amount of money—discriminates against the tourism industry.

As one whose electorate is based in a tourism area and the economy of which is wholly reliant on the tourism industry, I object to this proposal. I take this opportunity to point out that the test will come when this bill is voted on in the House of Representatives. The opposition's amendment, which seeks to provide equity for the tourism industry in relation to the EMDG scheme, was carried in the Senate. It is now up to the House of Representatives to deal with that amendment. The bottom line is that when we vote on this amendment it will be clear to the tourism industry in Australia who supports tourism and who does not.

I assure members of the government that those in the tourism industry are watching their performance with respect to this issue because it boils down to who supports the tourism industry and who does not. I am proud to stand in this place and say that the opposition strongly supports the tourism industry—we believe in tourism. We do not see much of the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee), but he pays lip-service to the tourism industry. When it comes to the crunch, he is unable to deliver on something as fundamentally important as the recognition of tourism as an export industry.

The industry wants that recognition. That is what a lot of the debate has been about. Tourism needs to be regarded as a fully fledged export industry. If it is recognised as such then there can be no argument for discriminating against it in respect of the EMDG scheme. I challenge the member for Reid and other government members who will be speaking in this debate to tell us why the government is not prepared to provide the tourism industry with the same access to the EMDG scheme as it provides for all other export industries in Australia. That is ultimately what this debate is about. We want to hear from the government why it will not give the tourism industry the same treatment.

The current EMDG scheme provides for grants to reimburse 50 per cent of eligible expenditure incurred above $15,000, subject to a minimum expenditure of $30,000 and a maximum grant of $250,000, which is to be reduced under this legislation to $200,000. We support that aspect of the legislation. Why is the extension of this scheme, which the tourism industry has been arguing and fighting for for many years, going to provide eligible single-service tourism providers a grant of only 25c in the dollar, within the broad eligibility criteria, when other exporters are entitled to 50c in the dollar?

Is there some rationale for that proposal other than what we heard in the Senate that the tourism industry is getting enough support or something along those lines. It is true that direct government support for the tourism industry has grown. I think the government's contribution to the Australian Tourist Commission has grown to around $100 million a year. We are certainly in favour of that assistance and acknowledge that that assistance is valued. When we vote on this legislation we will see whether the government is prepared to accept the amendment that was carried in the Senate.

A lot has been said about the tourism industry so far in this debate. Australia can be justifiably proud of this industry. It has grown consistently over the years, but largely despite the government. The government cannot claim much credit for what has happened in the tourism industry. As the member for Fadden (Mr Jull) rightly pointed out, the tourism industry has grown on the backs of a large number of small businesses in this country.

I see through the sheer hard work and dedication of some people in my electorate that many small businesses have recognised that Australia has something very special to offer as a tourism destination and that parts of Australia, such as the Gold Coast, have something particularly special to offer to Australians in terms of holidays. PARA.TAB: The tourism industry has grown very quickly and, as I said, that is pretty much because of the efforts of a large number of small businesses and a lot of people who are very committed to making this industry work.
