TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate your drawing this important standing order to the attention of my colleague.

PARA.TAB: The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration had quite a bit of input from tourism operators who made the point to us—the same point we are making in the course of this debate—that not only are they an export industry but also a number of them were being excluded from getting assistance under the EMDG scheme by virtue of the fact that they did not comply with the current criteria which, as I say, they then had to meet. The banking committee recommended that, once the export market development scheme had been fully implemented, consideration be given to the provision of equal access to the scheme for single-service providers at the rate of 50c in the dollar. I hope that the government will act on that recommendation.

Of course, there has not been a response to this report which was brought down in March 1995, but one should be forthcoming. I repeat: the committee, as a result of input from a lot of people in the tourism industry, recommended that the scheme be extended and that single-service tourism providers be provided access at the rate of 50c in the dollar.

I therefore challenge the government to support the amendment that has been carried by the Senate. It is an equitable amendment. It is an amendment which gives the tourism industry the support which it thoroughly deserves by virtue of the fact that it is one of the bigger industries in Australia; it is a big export earner for Australia. I am hoping that, when the matter comes up for a vote in this chamber, the government might see fit to accept the opposition's amendment which has been carried by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), more succinctly put the opposition's position than did others. I was interested earlier in listening to the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) who, in a very wide ranging exercise, covered the issues of the republic, the Pacific rim, industrial relations in this country, land rights, the Australian flag and, at the end of the debate, spent about two minutes on the issue we are considering today—the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill.

PARA.TAB: I also found it interesting that, whereas the previous speaker did a significant amount of pleading for special interests in his electorate and the predominance of the tourism industry within it, the lead spokesman for the opposition, as I indicated, really was not that interested in the issue at hand. As I said, he covered that broad expanse of issues. He made comments that governments have no role other than as facilitators. He lampooned or attempted to lampoon the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for his role on the international stage. In general, he came to the point of view that these kinds of grants are really very undesirable and, really, it is very unfortunate that we have them. I think that is a reasonably objective analysis of his contribution—that, really, he questioned the whole existence of the EMDG scheme.

In contrast, we have the previous speaker who wants to go to the other extreme. He says that the government has not been liberal enough in devoting taxpayers' money to this industry. He says that the $100 million—the amount which he indicated comes from the taxpayers—is a small bit of what is in the well.

In actual contrast, there is a very real reason why there should be a degree of, say, discrimination against this segment of the tourist industry. I was a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology which investigated this issue some years ago. Admittedly, that committee in recommendation No. 1 concluded:
The Committee recommends that the application of the Export Market Development Grants Scheme be extended to include all of the tourism industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I was the most doubtful member of that committee. I actually have extreme doubts as to the degree to which people visiting this country are persuaded to come here on the advertising effort of a particular hotel in Brisbane or Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you supported this recommendation.

—I supported the recommendation. But I also indicate that the government's response to it is perhaps closer to the reasonable mark in so far as there is a very valid claim that service providers will be piggybacking on the generic advertising that attracts people to this country, that they are not really the ones who attract people here, and that there must be a real question as to whether we should give them equal access to taxpayers' money. It is a very real question and I think the government's position is correct.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker referred to the cancellation of the scheme. It was in 1985, rather than 1987, from my recollection. It was accompanied, as evidenced before the committee, by a degree of fraudulent claims. It is interesting to note that people are coming forward with the concept that free samples should also be covered by taxpayers' largess.

There has been, since the reintroduction of it in 1990 from recollection, a discriminatory policy that says that the players in the industry were required to provide a number of services, whether it be transportation by land or water, accommodation, tourism escorts or admission to tourist attractions. Until now, there has been a requirement that operators in this service sector provide at least three of those facets of the industry.

The government, and anyone who looks at this industry rationally, says that the vast majority of tourists who come to this country come here because they are attracted to a diverse range of possibilities. They are not persuaded to come here by an advertisement on Hong Kong television for a particular hotel or motor car hiring company in Melbourne. They are coming to Australia because it provides a range of opportunities, a range of attractions.

It is ridiculous to say that there should not be any differentiation in this industry. We know that already there is differentiation in the operation of the act in the service industries—and perhaps this is something that should be reviewed again—as opposed to manufacturing. In the service industries it has to be specifically designated whereas in manufacturing, where there is over a 50 per cent local manufacturing contribution, it is mandatory that they are eligible. So, to my mind, there are grounds to conclude that there should be a distinction.

It is also worth noting that when the industry, science and technology committee made its recommendations it was careful to say that there should be no windfall profits to the industry by specifying that when it did come into operation the previous year's expenditure in this particular industry should not be counted towards EMDGS grants. So the committee was aware of the possibility of exploitation in the industry.

If we look at the overall question of the EMDGS, it has received a number of approving coverages by a variety of sources that it is of value to this country. Whereas some speakers on both sides of this House seem to feel that government activity, government intervention and support is a last-ditch effort, I am more persuaded by an article by Sydney University economist Evan Jones in this month's edition of FrontLine in which he comments:

Those commodity exports that fall outside the traditional categories include computers and parts (ranked 13th and 33rd), telecommunications equipment (18), cars (19), aircraft and equipment (20), boats (27), car engines and parts (28 and 38), and particular steel products (29 and 35). All of these commodities have been the subject of some sort of government support, either through explicit industry plans or through pragmatic subsidies.

Mainstream economists attribute all such successes to a `freeing-up' of the market, to the pressures induced on business by the great deregulatory steam train. There is possibly an element of truth in this; yet the relation between these `new' exports and government support is indisputable. All these packages have been developed pragmatically for specific reasons dictated by industry-specific balance of forces, and they all lie outside the conventional economic wisdom entrenched in the dominant policy vision.

No-one in Canberra has extrapolated from these particulars to the general principle. At the slightest sign of improvement in the current account, the government goes into `she'll be right mate' mode, proclaiming that the fundamentals are in place, and it's full steam ahead to current account utopia.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular scheme, as I say, has been the subject of a number of inquiries. It was covered by the industry, science and technology committee. It was also, as noted by previous speakers, the subject of the report Helping to meet the export challenge, wherein a number of recommendations and a number of analyses were made of the scheme. The report said of the scheme:

. . . the Government note that the EMDG scheme is achieving its objective of encouraging firms to seek out and develop export markets and that quantifiable, positive results flow through to the balance of payments from additional exports achieved . . .
The broad thrust of that report was positive towards the effect of the scheme. In regard to tourism it stated:
. . . taking into account the inter-relationship between generic and specific tourism promotion, and because there is an element of promotion directed at a "captive market"—
which I referred to earlier—

the Government may wish to consider applying a lower grant rate to tourism companies which would become eligible to claim. If so, the Government will need consider whether the lower grant rate should also apply to those tourism operators which are currently eligible under the scheme.

So that report was generally supportive of the success of the EMDG scheme and also said that perhaps there was some need to make a distinction in regard to how the EMDGS applies to the tourism industry, which the government is now attempting to do. The report also noted:
Revenues from taxes on grant receipts and profits on additional exports achieved are estimated to return 42% of the cost of the scheme to Government.

That is the kind of thing we have to see out of this. We have to see that there is some relationship between the government granting money and what Australia, industry and employment gain from the money; not just, as has been put, that it is discriminatory and wrong because everyone should get the same go at taxpayers' money. We have to ask whether it will have the effect desired. We have to make sure that there is a dollar return and that it is clearly interrelated; not just that tourism is growing, is producing jobs and is a worthwhile employer. There has to be an indication that this devotion of government money is achieving the results intended.

PARA.TAB: As I said, at the moment the legislation does distinguish clearly between the service and manufacturing industries, but that particular analysis of the EMDGS noted that much of the growth in the scheme has come from the service sector, despite the fact that it is not treated in the same fashion. The report further said:

SPEECH.PARA: The major scheme parameters, such as the minimum level of qualifying expenditure, the grant rate, number of grants and performance test, are broadly appropriate and changes are not recommended. Certain adjustments are recommended to improve the scheme, without change to the major parameters.
Predictably, the Auditor-General has also reviewed the EMDG scheme. Page xviii of Audit report No. 33 of 1993-94 noted that the EMDG scheme:
*achieves its objectives of encouraging firms to undertake export promotion which they would not otherwise have taken, and,
*in doing so generates export earnings in the order of $15-$20 for every $1 of grant for some categories of firms who have been in the scheme a number of years.
It further commented at page xiii:

The scheme is under pressure to expand, to be better focused, to provide a better value-added customer service, to become more efficient and to be less subject to misuse, but the data which can indicate the impact of the scheme, or even the potential number of EMDG clients, are not available.
It further said at page 42:
. . . as the scheme is narrowly defined and relatively isolated from other products, Austrade having decided that its resources are better focused elsewhere.

We have had a series of reports which say that this scheme in broad stance is operating well and that it is returning to taxpayers a significant amount of money for the dollars spent. No-one is disputing for a moment the contribution of tourism; it might not be as passionate an issue for those of us who do not have an electorate dependent upon it.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to look at the submission presented by Tourism Council Australia to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration in its current investigation into visa policy. In it Tourism Council Australia noted its expectation that in 1994 in this country tourism would generate $58.5 billion in gross output, account for 11.7 per cent of gross domestic product, create employment for one million people and contribute $15.6 billion in taxes. It further predicted that by 2005 tourism in Australia would generate $107 billion in gross output and employ 1.2 million people. It also mentioned the expansion from 1980 when Australia welcomed just over 900,000 visitors to a tripling of that number by the end of 1993. It also noted the industry expectation that it might accomplish the Australian Tourist Commission target of 6.8 million visitors for the year 2000.

It is indeed an industry, as both sides of the House have noted, that employs a large number of people, an industry that provides a significant amount of taxation and an industry that is also giving Australia a bigger dimension internationally. But it is worth noting that the motivation behind this current submission to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration is the issue of visa policy in this country.

The biggest argument the industry has put in is that there is a prevailing trend in international tourism now that people decide in a shorter time span to make visits. They do not wait around as they previously did for months and months to plan visits; they do it in a very short time. This strengthens the argument even more for precision in this grant. It is even more the case that they are making a split-second decision to go to a country; they do not go on the basis of an advertisement about a particular hotel, a particular motor car company or a particular one-off tourist attraction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah, but they do.

—Unlike the tourist industry in its expositions before the Joint Standing Committee on Migration and other committees, you are able to provide statistical material—and I will hear it later—as to the number of people who are attracted to this country on the basis of one hotel or Hertz rental cars! The industry, science and technology report notes on page xiii:

SPEECH.PARA: (ii) not only is it inequitable to have one sector of the tourism industry eligible for assistance . . . and other sectors not, but it is also inequitable that exporters of manufactured goods and other service exporters are eligible . . .

(iii) the exclusion of part of the tourism industry . . . will tend to encourage distortions in the allocation of investment resources. Resources may be directed towards industries which qualify for EMDGS assistance at the expense of tourism, leading to inefficiencies and to investments that are based on factors other than the merits and prospects of particular industries.
It further commented:

. . . marketing overseas by single tourism service providers may involve competition for market share, it cannot be assumed that it has little or no effect on the decision by tourists to visit Australia. Indeed, the evidence is that the choice of tourist destination is influenced by the promotion of a wide range of single services and attractions.

The difficulties in obtaining conclusive evidence of a causal link between the availability of government assistance for overseas market development and increased export revenues is something which must be dealt with when the EMDGS is next reviewed. Since it is not a difficulty which applies exclusively to the tourism industry . . . there is sufficient evidence for assistance to the tourism industry . . .
It further commented on page 30:
. . . anecdotal evidence—
they cannot prove a lot of these causal relationships, as I said—

received by the committee through submissions from inbound tourist operators suggest that claimants have increased their expenditure on overseas promotions, entered into cooperative marketing with the ATC, opened overseas offices and entered new markets that would not have otherwise been possible in the same time frame.

So there is a degree of uncertainty as to the relationship between single-service providers and their advertising efforts. There is an argument that perhaps there is a degree of wasteful competition. There is an argument as to whether it has the effect claimed. I for one do not think that it is good enough to say—and this has certainly not been the thrust of opposition arguments on other matters—that, because one sector gets something, everyone else has to get on the wagon or get on the gravy train. This is a very different argument from those opposite.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of other provisions in the legislation besides the substantive one we are arguing about. It opens up the applicability of the grants scheme to trade in South Africa after the recent momentous political changes there. It brings in some protections to try to ensure that there is not double-dipping by companies that are essentially part of the same corporation making a series of claims so that they are getting more than their fair share. It has penalties for a corporation of $50,000 and for an individual of $10,000 or five years imprisonment if they consciously seek to mislead as to the relationship between particular companies in the one operation in trying to claim more than their fair share.

There is also a calculation to be made in regards to companies which on the one hand are eligible tourist services and on the other are designated; in other words, the way moneys will be distributed between those that are single-service providers and those that provide a range of facilities. As I said, the essential thrust of the government's view is that they are undertaking different contributions to tourism in this country.

Finally, and this has been recommended previously, it makes departure taxes and visas eligible expenses in relation to the EMDGS. The 1994 Australian Trade Commission report, at page 39, commented that there was no good reason to allow the cost of international air travel and not associated airport departure taxes.

In conclusion, I hope that the government will not agree to the opposition amendments. I feel that it is a reasonable response to say that yes, there may be a contribution by individual sectors, there may be something they are doing, but essentially people come to this country because of generic advertising, because of the much heralded and promoted efforts of the Australian Tourism Council. They come here to see the outback, the beaches or other things. That is why they are coming to this country. They are not coming to this country because a particular hotel puts an advertisement on television. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1995. There are four major amendments proposed by the bill and three additional amendments that are now part of the bill. The former extends the life of the export market development grants scheme from 1994-95 to 1998-99, opens the way for single-service providers to claim eligibility, allows visa costs and departure taxes as eligible expenditure and limits related company groups to a maximum of $250,000 per year. The three other amendments are those that flowed from the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Undersold overseas, and include a provision to enable the tourism industry to form joint ventures and consortia, a provision to enable the cost of samples provided by the tourism industry to be accepted as eligible promotional expenditure and a provision to increase the grant rate in respect of designated tourism services to 50c.

PARA.TAB: The unfortunate fact is that, notwithstanding that the recommendations of the committee were bipartisan, the government, now the time has arrived for it to give these recommendations the tick, has just blithely rejected them. The export market development grants scheme provides a helping hand to Australia's export businesses, a helping hand that would probably not be necessary if the economic settings for this country were right. Instead, we have a taxation system that has exceeded its use-by date, a cut and paste of labour relations and a matrix of infrastructure services that for too long have hidden gross inefficiencies and contributed to overheads with which Australian export industries must contend.

What these costs have done collectively is to override Australia's international competitiveness. Such are the levels of costs and charges that Australian businesses are confronted with that we are having considerable difficulty in maintaining market share in our immediate region, and in fact in some markets we are going backwards. While I am on the subject of loss of market share, let me note the contribution that our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is making in this regard. In August 1993 he had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: When we brought the Corporate rate down from 49 per cent to 39 per cent, it was for that express purpose—to keep us competitive with the countries of the OECD and some in our region. You do look to see what the competitor country is doing and you make sure that your industries are on an equal footing. . .

Those are the words of the Prime Minister himself. Which members of the OECD or which of our regional neighbours have increased their company taxes from 33c to 36c? How has this increase in company tax helped our competitiveness?

PARA.TAB: In August last year, the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) said at the opening of what the government likes to describe as its pre-eminent conference on trade and investment, the national trade and investment outlook conference:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past decade Australia has undergone an economic transformation . . . 90 per cent of our manufacturing companies . . . do not export to any significant extent.

There is a transformation. The fact is that Australia's exporters have fallen into such a hole in terms of urgency that it is necessary to bail them out. The sad thing about it is that the government appears not to know how to go about resuscitating Australia's export performance. It is bereft of ideas.

PARA.TAB: The government is bereft of ideas to the extent that the government's trade policy, recently launched by the Prime Minister at the international conference on small business, drew a telling comment. Someone at the meeting, presumably from Australian small business, asked when they would see the final policy document. What did the Prime Minister launch? Obviously he launched the first draft. There is nothing in that document that would offer comfort to small business. Why? Because you cannot launch something like a trade policy without first making sure that the domestic economic settings have been addressed. Without a shadow of a doubt, the government, through its macro-economic settings, has become the Pol Pot of the Australian business community.

The other point about the first draft is that the government's policy on APEC remains incoherent. The coalition has been strongly supportive of APEC and has been bipartisan on anything to do with APEC issues. We believe that the leader's declaration at Bogor, committing the region to non-discriminatory trade liberalisation, was the way ahead for APEC.

We took some comfort that the government supported the same principles, but it is not so. The region has been thrown a pup by this government, which has got behind the United States and is now pursuing some shonky discriminatory trade agenda that is totally out of step with the rest of the region. The trade minister then has the gall to question the motives of the shadow minister for trade, who quite rightly challenged the government on the grounds that there had been a policy shift that had major implications for the whole region. Clearly, this new agenda is at odds with the rest of the region.

Let us not stop at the regional policy incoherence. Last Friday our trade minister, leaving aside the fact that he was to announce the government's trade policy, delivered an address to the National Press Club on the imbalance of Australia's trade with the United States. It is a matter of record that the government has been dealing with the United States, unfortunately with little tangible result, in an effort to influence the US to drop subsidised dairy produce and grain into Asia on the dairy export incentive program and on the export enhancement program.

The minister informed his audience that the United States is blocking Australia's trade to the tune of $1 billion. He highlighted, and rightly so, the disparity in trade policy with Japan and the US policy towards Australia. His own department released figures showing that Australia's exports to the US had declined by over 20 per cent over the last five years. What he does not say is how Australian business regains a greater market access. Where are the strategies that will make this happen? It is fine to draw attention to the situation, but there is no policy coherence that will deliver outcomes. It becomes all a matter of hot air.

In making my final comments on the bill, I have two things to say. Firstly, the level of consultation with the recipients of the scheme, especially those affected by the reduction in the amount of $250,000—namely, company groups—was, judging from the representations made to the coalition, appalling. Nevertheless, we are prepared to accept the proposals providing it can be shown that no group participant will be affected. Secondly, I make the observation that, while welcoming the inclusion of single-service providers, there is a distinction in grant rates between these applicants and all other applicants that are in receipt of the grant of 50c in the dollar. I raise that in the interests of consistency.

Furthermore, in the interests of the tourism industry, a major revenue earner, I ask the government to accept, in the true spirit of bipartisanship, the other two amendments proposed in the bill. They deal with three things, as previous coalition speakers have said, including provision for the tourism industry to claim the cost of samples given away to overseas visitors. This is a very important aspect.

I might just deviate here to show how silly the laws we make in relation to promotion of tourism sometimes are and how they can act against us. The Bundaberg Rum Distillery in my electorate gives samples to people in much the same way as people who go to wineries can sample the product. But the Bundaberg Rum Distillery has to pay excise on its samples. The sample is a product the distillery gives away freely. It is a product that promotes tourism in Australia. It is a sample that promotes one of Australia's best known products. Yet, for all that, with no sale taking place, the product is still subject to excise. What we are saying in this legislation is that samples offered by the tourism industry to overseas visitors should become eligible for the export market development grant subsidy.

The other thing I would like to say—and I take umbrage at some of the comments made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson)—is that for some reason there is a belief that the tourism industry is `that other industry'; that group of industries that is glamorous and gets by on its own; that we do not have to worry about it, except to find all the reasons why it has captive markets and things like that; and that, for that reason, it should be deprived of subsidy levels available to other industries.

This industry employs the most Australians. This is our greatest export earner. This is the glamour industry around which we build such events as the coming Olympic Games, yet we treat it, in matters such as the export market development grant, as a second-class citizen. We say to this industry, `You can be part of the scheme, but at only 25c in the dollar.' Quite frankly, I do not think that is good enough, and I believe it sends out the wrong message to the tourist industry.

We have all seen the international projections for tourism by the year 2000 and the year 2005. There is no guarantee that Australia's growth will increase on the same exponential curve it has in the past. There is no guarantee of that at all. Other nations are becoming smarter in their promotion. Other nations have seen how we have done it. Asia is freeing up in quite a dramatic way. We are not going to have to be the best; we are going to have to be better than the best. For that reason, the coalition amendment to have the subsidy raised to 50c in the dollar is only fair. It is the only way we can send out the right message to the tourist industry and ensure that we stay ahead in terms of the promotion of tourism in South-East Asia and the world.

I would like to echo the words of the member for Fadden (Mr Jull) when he said that 92 per cent of all businesses in tourism are small businesses. To some extent, he has stolen part of my thunder in respect of regional tourism. Regional tourism has played an incredible part in the development of a national matrix of interstate, intrastate and overseas visitation. Australians cannot survive on sporting events, Sydney, Ayers Rock, the Gold Coast or Cairns alone. It is not that these are unimportant as major magnets in attracting people to Australia—they are vitally important.

Australia depends on a range of diverse experiences to satisfy the international visitor. In reply to the previous speaker, let me say that I was never suggesting for a minute that people come here because of Avis car rentals, Hertz Rent A Car or the Sheraton Hotel. They come here because of diverse experience. For that reason, you have to take into account the whole matrix of tourism when looking at something like the export market development grant.

I was a manager of a regional tourism authority for 12 years and I never ceased to wonder at the contribution of small operators—not only to their own promotions but to promotions on a regional scale. That is part of the reason why you can travel from Melbourne to Cairns and go through so many marvellous areas, whether it be Coffs Harbour or the Gold Coast—and I am sorry that Deputy Speaker Nehl is no longer in the chair—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Or Wollongong.

TALK.START.PARA: —or Wollongong, or a whole host of other places and experiences. For the entire journey—through the cane fields, the Barrier Reef and along the inland road—there is a diverse pattern. It is not just the great major resorts that hold the fabric together. A lot of little operators act jointly with their regional tourism authorities.

PARA.TAB: Queensland has 13 regional tourism authorities. I suppose you could say that four of them are in quite glamorous locations—Brisbane, Gold Coast, the Whitsundays and Cairns. But there are nine other authorities that hold the fabric of tourism together. If it were not for the regions, there would be a gross imbalance and gaps in the range of tourism product.

These small operators that I have been talking about go to road shows—they go off in buses and promote—and attend trade shows, expos and sales interfaces with the industry. They are always sharing the cost of regional tourism promotion with the local tourism authorities. It seems to me that operators that are so motivated, so focused and so cooperative have earned the right to participate in overseas promotions. It is generally not recognised that few of these operators could participate in overseas promotions in their own right, let alone become eligible for an export market development grant in their own right.

The coalition's amendment goes some way to addressing the flaw in the government's program. It would be capricious of the government to force the withdrawal of this amendment. It is so important to allow two or three operators to get together. The government will be depriving a vast range of participants access to tourism markets if it throws this amendment out.

Let me also express a personal view that takes that vision a bit further. Perhaps this is a debate for another day, but I would like to touch on it briefly in the context of this debate. I believe that regional tourism authorities should be eligible for funding when they coordinate and participate in overseas promotions involving export market development grants and when other eligible individuals or companies are involved.

The government postures loud and long about regional development and regional economic development, yet the delivering body—the regional tourism authority, the body that state and federal governments rely upon for the delivery of programs, studies, submissions and coordinated promotions—is sidelined when it comes to something as fundamental as an export development grant. There seems to me to be an elementary lack of logic in this attitude. Frequently, the regional tourism authority is the very motivator of and originator of the away from home promotions. These promotions do not just happen. Certainly, you might get two or three promoters together—as the member for Fadden talked about with Quicksilver in North Queensland.

In those other nine regions, the organisation that pulls those small operators together—those operators might not be the big motels, the big attractions, the big services to the Barrier Reef or the big tour companies—is the regional tourist authority. It brings all those operators together, puts a promotional theme together, prepares the material and takes that promotion around the state or interstate.

I cannot for the life of me see why that same body which does so much motivating, so much originating and so much accessing on behalf of the industry should not be eligible for government export facilitation subsidies to take those smaller regions into the international market. What we would see out of that would be not so much groups of overseas tourists coming to specific spots in Australia, as indeed the Japanese do with the Gold Coast and various other groups do with Sydney and Ayers Rock; we would see a better spread of tourism up and down the east coast, into the north-west of Australia and to the southern states.

I appeal to the government to consider not knocking out the three amendments put up by the coalition and in particular to allow joint venturing as part of the export market development grants scheme. I hope the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay), who is at the table and who comes from a regional area, conveys that to the minister. He would know the truth of what I am saying. I trust that he and others in the government will convey that to the minister and see that this very important scheme, which has been going since 1974, continues to function on behalf of not just the big players in Australian tourism but all players.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have an opportunity to speak on the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill for some of the same reasons already well described by my colleague the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) and my colleague the member for Fadden (Mr Jull). Being the shadow minister for small business, I know that 92 per cent of tourism businesses in this country, as the member for Fadden pointed out, are small businesses. On the regional development side, I support the member for Hinkler in that many of our regional areas today rely on the growth of tourism to sustain them through what has been a period of drought and difficulty for them. They have looked for new markets and have turned increasingly to developing tourism potential within those regions. So I have a particular interest in the amendment bill being debated today.

PARA.TAB: The export market development grants scheme was introduced in 1974-75. I think there lies a problem. In 1974-75, Australia was probably only just beginning to get a small inkling of its potential as a tourist destination. It has really been in the 1980s and the 1990s that we have seen a greater development of our potential as a tourist destination. The original export market development grants scheme was introduced in 1974-75 to encourage Australian firms to seek export markets for their products and to promote an export culture in the Australian business community. Those were days perhaps when Australia was more greatly focused on its resources, its manufacturing bases and its other areas of commerce but not so heavily attuned to the benefits of developing tourism in this country.

The bill we are debating today proposes that the export market development grants scheme be extended for a fifth time, from 1994-95 to 1998-99. The coalition will support this extension but not before proposing some very sensible and important amendments to the government's bill to, as usual, improve the outcome for the business community and, I might say, deliver fairness and equity. I think it is quite wrong to make benefits available to some sections of the commercial community and not make them available to others. In this case, the tourism industry will miss out unless the government takes notice of what the coalition has said in relation to this and accepts the coalition's amendments to fully include the tourism industry.

The export market development grants scheme currently provides taxable grants of up $250,000 per annum or $500,000 for approved trading houses and is based primarily on expenditure incurred by an Australian person or company seeking to create or expand exports of their products in overseas markets. Provided people have incurred at least $30,000 of eligible expenditure in a grant year, they are then entitled to a grant which is calculated at 50 per cent of eligible expenditure after the first $15,000—that is, unless their business happens to be a single-service tourism provider. Export market development grant claimants are limited to a maximum of eight grants, each one limited to a maximum of $250,000. Therefore, $2 million is potentially available for each claimant to promote and enhance the development of export markets.

During the period of 1992-94, approximately 5,750 export market development grants were paid totalling $376 million. These statistics highlight the number of successful applicants but, unfortunately, do not identify the number of companies that have found the process of applying for EMD grants either too complicated or out of their reach due to the impact of the threshold expenditure levels or, in the case of single-service tourism operators, do not identify their exclusion altogether from the scheme.

The major amendments proposed by this bill give effect to the recommendations of a 1994 evaluation of the export market development grants scheme entitled Helping to meet the export challenge: an evaluation of the export market development grants scheme and the international trade enhancement scheme. The key findings of the recommendations in this evaluation were that the export market development grants scheme is achieving its objective of encouraging firms to seek out and develop export markets; revenues from taxes on grant receipts and profits on additional exports were estimated to return 42 per cent of the cost of the scheme to the Commonwealth; most of the growth in the export market development grants scheme has come from the service sector; the minimum level of qualifying expenditure, the grant rate, number of grants and performance tests are largely appropriate; the number of firms claiming grants and then dropping out of the EMDG scheme is not ideal; the EMDG scheme should be extended to all claimants in the tourism sector; and the EMDG scheme should be extended for a further five years.

One of the major features of these amendments is to extend the reach of the export market development grants scheme to single-service tourism operators who are currently excluded from the benefits of the scheme. Altogether, until this time, they have not been part of that scheme.

However, despite the fact that the tourism industry is close to earning $12 billion a year in export earnings for Australia—more than the cumulative export earnings from iron ore, wheat, alumina, aluminium, sugar, and petroleum—single-service tourist operators are to be allowed to access the export market development grants scheme at only 50 per cent of the rate of all other individuals and companies in Australia.

Although the government in this amendment bill is saying it now recognises and includes the tourist industry and the single-service tourist operator, and is going to include them in this scheme, it is only going to give them half of what other companies or individuals in Australia are entitled to. This is another example of this government treating small businesses as second-class citizens, given that 92 per cent of those businesses in the tourism industry are small businesses.

The tourism industry has the capacity for further substantial expansion as a result of increasing market activity led by strong expenditure by overseas visitors to Australia. The flow-on benefits emanating from these visitors are not restricted to tourist ventures; all associated businesses and industries benefit. Not just the tourism sector benefits from the additional attraction of tourists into this country; there is a flow-on effect to many people in the community.

The benefits of tourism are spread throughout the country because tourists have a habit of visiting friends, relatives and attractions throughout all areas of the Australian landscape. This is a wonderful way of redistributing income and benefits without the Labor Party's arcane methods of doing so. These amendments fail to remove the inherent discrimination against rural and regional tourist operators and small businesses who are, in many instances, unable to develop valuable export markets without the benefit of assistance in the developmental stage of export market development.

Typical of the government's lack of foresight in promoting small business, the 1994 evaluation of the EMDG scheme, Helping to meet the export challenge: an evaluation of the export market development grants scheme and the international trade enhancement scheme, identified that revenues from taxes on grant receipts and profits on additional exports were estimated to return 42 per cent of the cost of the scheme to the Commonwealth, and that is significant.

It is estimated that for every 17 overseas visitors, one additional Australian job is created. Many of the young people viewing the proceedings in this chamber today could be recipients of jobs in the tourism sector. The government should be extending, on a full parity basis, single-service tourism providers' access to this scheme, because they belong to the small business sector that, during the five years to May 1994—that was after the recession—created employment growth in Australia of 563,000 or 18 per cent.

During the same period, employment in big business and in government fell by 9.5 per cent and 7.2 per cent respectively. While government and big business were shedding jobs, small business was increasing its take-up of Australians into employment. Every dollar of EMDG assistance allocated is far more likely to generate maximum return from the small business sector than from other sectors of the economy.

The amendments proposed in this bill clearly illustrate that this government does not understand the intricacies of the operation of the tourism industry. The tourism industry is denied the right to include the cost of providing samples as part of eligible promotional expenditure. My friend the member for Hinkler has already given us a very good illustration of that. This is one anomaly that must be corrected to ensure that equity is maintained for all grant recipients.

Tourism is one of the most fiercely competitive industries in the world, with all countries attempting to maximise the number of people visiting and then ensure that their stay is as long as possible. As the member for Fadden rightly pointed out, it is not just the big hotels and big companies that are benefiting from this. By far the large majority of tourists to this country are spending in smaller establishments. This all adds up and is very important to our overall economic wellbeing.

As with any other export industry, the key factors of the tourism market are high quality products, available at competitive prices, with a focus on customer requirements. Each of these factors is critical to the success of the Australian tourism export market. Promotion is an integral and critical component of any export strategy. Our tourism industry has done an excellent job of promoting the intrinsic value of Australia's tourist attractions. Tourism growth did not just happen. It has come about as a result of intensive marketing by theme parks, resorts, hotels, tourism authorities, airlines, inbound tour operators—and the list goes on. For the government to exclude the cost of promotion of tourist attractions from eligibility for the EMDG scheme is both short-sighted and, in my view, inequitable.

Other amendments proposed by this bill will enhance the efficiency of the export market development grants scheme and enable the benefits of the scheme assistance to be available for a greater number of Australian exporters. The move to place a limitation of $200,000 per company group per grant year will ensure that available funds are widely distributed across a broader range of exporters. This amendment complements the access of exporters to only one of the range of Austrade assistance measures at any one time with respect to a specific project. This will overcome the propensity for some companies to double-dip across a range of Austrade schemes, thereby reducing the level of financial contribution from the exporter.

A similar observation can be made of the budget decision to reduce the maximum grant payable from $250,000 to $200,000. The reduction of the maximum grant payable will ostensibly enable more small and medium sized enterprises to access the export market development grants scheme in any one year. As we have come to expect, the inconsistency of government decision making impacts in many perverse ways. The budget decision to increase the company tax rate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent will reduce the value of export market development grants by nine per cent, as all grants are taxable in the hands of recipients. It would be incorrect to assume that small and medium sized businesses in Australia are not affected by measures to increase company tax.

We have also created additional problems for those in our business community seeking export grants, by imposing additional tax measures on them. This is just another example of the government giving with one hand and taking with the other. As I have said many times in speeches relating to the budget, it is a bit of a pea and thimble trick: you see it here and it is taken away there.

Industry sources state that the average sized export market development grant is approximately $60,000. On this basis, the increase in the company tax rate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent, which was announced during the budget, will reduce the level of funds available for export market development or recompense of expenses already paid from an average $60,000 by a further $5,400.

For companies that had previously been eligible for the maximum grant of $250,000, the impact of the budget decisions will result in, firstly, an increase in taxation of $22,500 per maximum grant—that is not an insignificant amount for a small business—and, secondly, a reduction of $50,000 or 20 per cent in the value of the export market development grant available. It is quite a significant reduction in the amount available. So much for this government's commitment to export development.

Other technical aspects of the bill which I wish to comment on briefly relate to the inclusion of departure taxes and visa costs as eligible expenses. This is an overdue amendment and is due recognition of the fact that these expenses are legitimate costs associated with export market promotion. The prevention of payment of grants to persons where they refuse to allow a search of criminal records for the purpose of the criminal conviction provision of the Export Market Development Grants Act is also a recognition of the fact that funds must be directed to companies and individuals of the highest probity.

The strengthening of the penalty provisions where a person provides false or misleading material or statements in support of a claim or for a grant will help to ensure that individuals and companies seeking export market development grant assistance do so on the basis of the provision of true and accurate supporting documentation, and that is critical. The repeal of the restrictive provisions relating to the proscribing of the Republic of South Africa for the purpose of the Export Market Development Grants Act recognises the changes that have occurred in the Republic of South Africa and correctly recognises that trade between South Africa and Australia is now being conducted to the benefit of both countries.

Finally, another technical aspect of the bill that I wish to comment on is the introduction of more effective powers to prevent abuse where persons buy, sell, transfer or modify business undertakings in a manner which would make them eligible for grants in excess of the general grant limit. The nature of these technical amendments will tighten a number of existing provisions and lead to a greater degree of compliance with the broad provisions of the Export Market Development Grants Act. The coalition has already initiated a number of amendments to this bill in the Senate, and I support their inclusion in the bill. They are critical to the deliverance of equity to the tourist market.

I would like to raise a few other matters that are not covered by the amendments included in this bill. They relate to the complexity of the application process which needs to be simplified to allow easy access and entry into the scheme. These amendments do not address the large number of recipients of grants who, after receiving the first grant, subsequently drop out of the scheme. There is significant leakage of benefits to other firms.

Access to Austrade services, particularly the export market development scheme, by regional businesses is hampered due to difficulty in obtaining information and consultation with Austrade personnel who in many instances are located in either Canberra or Sydney or are restricted to capital cities. Do you want to see a graph? There it is. That is you down there, John. Despite the fact that we had the worst recession in 60 years, we had these levels of interest rates shown.
—It was not 60 years, Ralph.
—Going back 60 years, the worst one was that one. The official interest rates were 9.9 per cent when the now Leader of the Opposition left office as Treasurer. They are 7 1/2 per cent today.
—What were they in real terms?
—Order! The member for Mayo!

—You had inflation through the roof! Ninety day bank bills were 15.9 per cent. They are 7.7 per cent or thereabouts today. The prime interest rate was 15.75 per cent when the now Leader of the Opposition resigned as Treasurer. Today it is around 10.7 per cent. We are seeing, therefore, interest rates which are far below those that were left to us by the Leader of the Opposition, even under his highly regulated regime in which he had interest rates locked up with regulations, a lot of which do not exist today, and a monetary policy committee of cabinet determining the outcomes, rather than the Reserve Bank deciding on official interest rate policy. You did not have a reserve bank operating out there in the free way it operates now. You had the monetary policy committee of cabinet and the members of the Reserve Bank hanging around outside the door waiting to find out what the policy was. Even with that you had interest rates through the roof.

PARA.TAB: Do not lecture us about low interest rates. This government is giving this country rates which are relatively low compared with those given by the previous government, rates which are not high by the general level of Western countries. It is doing so in circumstances where the budgetary policy before this parliament is designed to assist us to maintain that relatively low level interest rate regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. What is the government doing to research the special needs of older people and contribute to their healthy ageing?

—Although it seems to dismay the opposition, I think it is important that in this parliament we do from time to time talk about social and health policy, particularly policy related to the ageing. It seems that the opposition has no interest in these matters except to mouth platitudes. But the government is committed to working with older Australians to make sure that they can maintain a healthy and continuing participation in community life.

PARA.TAB: We have actually shown a very strong commitment through our time in government and have a proud record of action over the last 10 years. We have significantly increased the options that are available to older Australians. An example of this is the massive expansion of the home and community care program—over 200 per cent in real terms. Most members would be aware of this program. But we are not resting on our laurels. We are outlining new initiatives, looking for further improvements. But we hear nothing from the opposition on these matters.

To the end of improving our performance, we are sponsoring several important projects, which I am sure will be of interest to members. Firstly, we are providing funds to La Trobe University to analyse the mental and physical factors that affect the outlook of older Australians on growing older. Secondly, we are providing funds to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of treatment for late life depression. We do not want to see our older citizens depressed and alone. We are also working on a project to look at the isolation of older women, particularly after their partners have died. We are also providing $114,000 to the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation to produce a video on preventing falls—a significant problem in elderly communities.

Another key area of concern in the elderly community is dementia care. Today I announced a major new study to improve that care. That study will identify the number and characteristics of those people who have dementia and consider how best to house and care for them. There is a lot of dispute on this matter. In addition, we are providing $1.6 million for dementia counselling services. Most of that money will go to state Alzheimer associations to build on the very good work they are doing right now—providing support for sufferers and their carers.

In all of this, we are listening very carefully to the community and responding to people's needs. All we have heard from the opposition to date is that it intends to listen to the industry. We do not know what it intends to do in the area of aged care to support those carers and families. We know the opposition's policy on families is about slashing wages to families, income splitting to help the wealthy, undermining Medicare and favouring owners and operators in the health care system over the users of those services. Until we hear something from the opposition, we can only assume the worst of it, and I think that is absolutely correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. If not, will you repudiate the Prime Minister's deceitful, absolutely overblown comments yesterday equating tax bills with supply?

—I certainly was not being a complete hypocrite by arguing for a certain policy and then taking measures to destroy it, which is what you are doing. In 1981 what we said was that we did not believe your policies were the right policies and that we were opposing them. We did not believe that there should be fiscal tightening because you were leading us into recession—the worst recession for 60 years. So we were right. You were pursuing policy which was bad policy—the wrong policy.
—Oh, Ralph! Sit down.
—The honourable member for Mayo!

—We were not saying to you, `Listen, you should be tightening fiscal policy, but we are going to oppose your measures anyway.' That is what you are saying to us. You are saying to us, `You should be tightening fiscal policy, but we are going to oppose your measures.' We were not being the hypocrites that you are. That is the fundamental and absolute difference.
—Ha, ha!
—Stupid laughter will not change that point one bit.
—Order! Those on my left! The Treasurer has the call and he will be heard in silence.
—Keep going; have an extension of time.
—The Leader of the Opposition is not helping me.

—There is that fundamental difference between what happened in 1981 and what is happening now. Let me remind the House of what was happening then. We had before us a proposition from the government of the day that we should increase sales taxes. This involved a broadening of the sales tax base.
—Tell us about what you are doing.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—So what do you reckon the extension of the wholesale sales taxes was going to be put on? Building materials? Yes, all building materials, plus clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, books, newspapers, periodicals, wrapping paper and so on. When the present Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer he was proposing an enormous extension of the tax base on a vast array of items. There was going to be a tax on all building materials, plus an extension of the wholesale sales tax on all of these other items. We opposed that extension.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the wholesale sales tax at that time, this meant that, in one blow, the then Treasurer was going to increase revenue under the wholesale sales tax by 42 per cent. He was going to do that in one go and at a time when the economy was going down the plughole and we were going into the worst recession in 60 years.

We stand by the action that we took at that time. It was the appropriate action because we were not being hypocritical. We were saying, `Your policy is wrong; you should not be tightening fiscal policy and we oppose it for that reason.' The opposition is in the utterly hypocritical position of saying to us, `You should be tightening fiscal policy, but we are going to oppose all your measures to do it.' That is totally different from 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. What action is the government taking to make the law and the legal system work more effectively for business?

—Members might be aware that to be debated in the Senate this week—if the Senate actually gets around to passing some legislation—is the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill. This is an important bill for improving the law relating particularly to small businesses in terms of removing unnecessary paperwork and constraints on the operation of small business.

PARA.TAB: On Thursday, I will launch the Second Corporate Law Simplification Bill as an exposure draft. This is a much larger bill than the first and covers a great deal of the core company law areas in this country. It will touch on the reform of areas such as company formation, company names, company meetings and important rules dealing with share capital, accounts, audits and annual returns. With the completion of this stage of the corporations law simplification project—that is, the passage of the second bill—most of the core company law areas which impact particularly on small business will have completely gone through a process of simplification.

In addition to that important program, the government's Justice Statement outlined a range of measures which are particularly directed at the operation of Australian business, as well as business obviously benefiting from the general measures dealing with improvements to the legal profession, the development of a national legal services market and the greater emphasis and support for the development of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

One program was targeted at small business and its capacity to take legal action—the establishment of the national disbursement fund. This fund, unlike smaller funds which operate in the states, will be able to be accessed by corporations and small business. It will not be excluded in any way in terms of commercial law matters, which is often the way in which legal aid and similar disbursement funds operate at the state level.

This reform, together with changes to contingency fees, means that, if smaller Australian businesses are in dispute with a larger business and need to undertake certain expert reports and outlays in obtaining those expert reports, they will be able to access the contingency disbursement fund. This will be a major chance for small Australian businesses to have greater access to the legal system. This, combined with the improved corporations law system and the reforms to consultation with business which are hand in hand with the improvements to the way in which we make delegated legislation—which is of course where most of the regulation confronting business is to be found—is a comprehensive package to make our legal system operate better for small Australian businesses.

—By invitation of the Treasurer, I seek leave to table this list of products that—

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. What is the government's response to the recent criticism of the model criminal code in the journal, the Australian Lawyer? What progress has been made towards national criminal laws? How committed is the government to this process?

—I thank the honourable member for that question. There was criticism by Mr Justice Thomas of the Queensland Supreme Court in the most recent edition of that journal. It is very fortunate for members from both sides of this House who joined in supporting the initiative on the model criminal code that in fact that criticism is very much a minority view.

PARA.TAB: The former Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, was very much instrumental in terms of the design of the way in which this new legislation has evolved. A number of other senior members of the judiciary—for example, Mr Justice Murray in Western Australia, who has also been involved in similar reform initiatives—are extremely complimentary of the process. That is not really surprising given that the process is one which has involved not only the Commonwealth but also almost all the other states in terms of the development through a working party, which has involved state and Commonwealth senior legal officers working together, along with the process of very extensive consultation with the private profession and all other interested groups.

It is absurd in a country such as Australia that if you cross a state boundary the principles of criminal responsibility and criminal law change, not merely the nature of the crimes themselves. We are working to harmonise that now not only with the agreement of the state attorneys but also with a commitment of the Prime Minister and all state premiers to reach the objective of harmonised criminal laws by the year 2001. In the Justice Statement that the Prime Minister launched with the Attorney-General and me, we committed ourselves to further funding of $800,000 so we could ensure those time lines were met.

In this House we have already passed the general principles of criminal responsibility legislation. That came into effect on 31 March. We will be moving through the process of making sure that all other Commonwealth criminal legislation is adapted to fit in with those principles. Two other stages will shortly be before the parliament: the first on crimes of theft, corruption and similar property offences and the second on violent crimes—issues such as murder, rape and the like. Those matters will be coming before the parliament, again having been through a process which involved the most detailed consultation possible.

In conclusion, there is one matter I would like the House to be aware of because it rounds off what has been a very constructive process—that is, the one jurisdiction which has stood out from the process to date has been Victoria. I am very pleased to tell the House that we were advised earlier this week that the Victorian government is re-entering the process and is rejoining the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee. We can now speak to a national common purpose to this very important end.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer him to an assessment I released last Sunday which shows that the lowest paid employee will be $8.25 per week worse off in real terms under Accord Mark VIII. In response, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training disputed the assessment arguing that compulsory employee superannuation contributions represent deferred pay. Does this not mean that until the deferred pay is in fact paid in 2042 the lowest paid will be worse off?
—You are a log.
—Order! I warn the member for the Northern Territory.

—It is a particularly cute definition of take-home pay to include superannuation contributions as part of the tax process. Superannuation contributions are savings on behalf of individuals which not only are put aside for their future benefit but also are matched by the government. Rather than include those savings—as the honourable member did in his analysis, just as tax is to be taken away and disregarded before some outcome is arrived at about supposed reduced real wages—these are amounts which are being put aside for the future retirement of these people.

PARA.TAB: Superannuation contributions are savings being made now which will be matched by the government. Those savings will be worth twice their nominal amount. The amounts deducted will be virtually completely matched by the government through the terms of its co-contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —So they are worse off?
—Order! The member for Flinders!

—They are not worse off. They are making savings for their future. It is a new definition of being worse off to say that any money you save means you are worse off. That presumably means that if you put money into the bank then you are worse off. It is a great definition of `saving' if in this country or any country you say that any money you save means you are worse off. What a ridiculous proposition it is to say that money that is put into an account in a person's name for their future benefit should be regarded as having no benefit for them. It is an absurd proposition. The reality of life is that the amounts which are being put aside are being matched by the Commonwealth so they are doubly beneficial to the individual.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Tourism. Considering that Japan is Australia's single largest tourism market, what is the government doing to improve our market share given increased competition by tourist destinations such as Hawaii? What effects has the Kobe earthquake had on Japanese travel to Australia? Could the minister outline any particular benefits these initiatives will have for my home state of Queensland?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. As you are well aware, a minister is not permitted to announce government policy or to be asked about an announcement of policy by way of a question. I draw your attention to the first part of that question and invite you to rule accordingly.
—I understood the question was not inviting a government policy announcement and the minister would certainly be aware of that. I call the Minister for Tourism.
—I am not sure what question the point of order was about.
—It is the one you have written out in front of you!
—The Minister for Tourism has the call.
—I invite the Leader of the National Party to read the media clippings on what is actually happening in relation to Cathay Pacific.
—You had better hurry; choir practice starts at 4 p.m.

—I thought the Kobe earthquake would have been of interest even to the member for Mayo. It is a pity that he thinks that this is a laughing matter. This natural disaster caused a tremendous loss of life and massive disruption to the Kobe-Osaka region of Japan. I commend the Japanese and Australian businesses and those individuals from both countries that have sought to provide assistance to people who have been affected by that earthquake. Supplies have been sent to the Kobe region and a number of people who have been most directly affected by the earthquake—those who lost members of their families—have been offered respite with a holiday in Australia. I particularly commend those people who have provided this assistance without seeking any public recognition for the assistance that they have provided.

PARA.TAB: There was concern in the tourism industry that this earthquake would cause a downturn in the number of travellers from Japan to Australia. I am pleased to tell the House that, despite that concern, the number of travellers coming to Australia has rebounded quite strongly from the relatively subdued performance in February and March of this year. In fact, we had 10 per cent growth in the number of Japanese travellers coming to Australia in April. I am sure that we are all pleased about that.

These figures, together with the latest market intelligence from the Australian Tourist Commission, show that, despite the intense competition from Hawaii, the Kobe earthquake will probably not have the impact we expected on the number of Japanese travellers coming to Australia. This is very important given the number of questions from the opposition today relating to our balance of payments.

Japanese tourists coming to Australia for holidays generated more than $2.8 billion in export earnings for Australia. Almost four out of every five Japanese travellers who came to Australia in 1994 went to Queensland during their holidays. With more than half a million Japanese tourists travelling to Queensland on holidays and spending money there they are responsible for creating a lot of jobs in the member's home state and, no doubt, in his electorate of Leichhardt. This is in no small measure due to the superb job that Bob Gibbs, the Queensland minister, and the QTTC do to market that state as a destination not just for travellers from Japan but for travellers from many other countries in the region. Most other state and territory tourist commissions are quite envious of the sums of money that the QTTC has to spend to promote Queensland in the region.

To ensure that Australia continues to benefit from the export earnings that flow from the number of Japanese travellers coming to Australia, I can tell the House that in October this year the Australian Tourist Commission plans to hold a summit in Japan of leading figures involved in the tourism industry from both Australia and Japan. We hope that that summit will continue to make sure that we are making the most of this market.

Honourable members might also be interested in the Australian Tourist Commission's planned marketing campaign for the next three years, which will involve a total expenditure by the Australian government of over $100 million. The new advertisements, which are currently being filmed in locations right around Australia, will include one new advertisement for Japan. That will also help to broaden our market so that we are not just targeting honeymoon couples and young women. We will also be seeking to encourage more young Japanese people who are interested in an adventure holiday. No doubt they will often visit the honourable member's own region of Cairns. We are also trying to encourage more young Japanese families—perhaps couples as well as their kids—to make sure that we are encouraging more investment in the Australian tourism industry and creating more jobs. This is something that I would have thought would have the support of both sides of the House.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Can the minister inform the House of the outlook for Australia's mineral and energy exports and what the government is doing to encourage investment and growth in our mineral sector.

—I thank the honourable member for Throsby for his question. As members would be aware, ABARE released its figures last year which show that commodity prices are increasing and that there is strong economic growth in our export market.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister can just wait a moment. Those on my left! The provisions of standing order 55 apply right throughout a parliamentary sitting day. The minister has the call.

—I thank you, Mr Speaker. The total value of Australia's commodity exports in 1995-96 will increase by 13 per cent to $56 billion. The major proportion of the increase is expected to come from the mineral resources sector, with only a relatively small increase coming from the rural sector—obviously due to the drought and the rural downturn. Minerals and energy exports earnings are forecast to increase in both 1994-95 and 1995-96. They are forecast to rise by five per cent in 1994-95 to some $31.4 billion.

PARA.TAB: The forecast increase in both these years reflects higher export prices and volumes for minerals and energy commodities. Higher coal and iron ore contract prices negotiated in early 1995 will contribute strongly to higher sector export earnings in 1995-96. However, aluminium, gold and oil exports are also expected to increase strongly.

I hasten to inform the House that the Australian minerals sector is not by any means sitting on its hands, reaping windfall gains from these increases in mineral prices. The industry accounts for one-quarter of the total business investment in this country, and I am pleased to note that investment is forecast to grow strongly.

New capital investment in the mining industry alone was $5.6 billion in 1993-94; it will grow to an impressive $7 billion in 1994-95. It is reinvesting more every year in mineral projects and, in particular, in the further value adding and processing of mineral products in Australia. For example, in Western Australia in the Pilbara region alone, some $4 billion is under consideration for value adding and processing investments. The most advanced of these is a $750 million investment by BHP in a hot briquette iron plant at Port Hedland. A final decision on this project is expected in the next two months.

The honourable member asked what government policy was doing to encourage further investment. Obviously, through the COAG process, gas reform has led to significant changes in the way Australian mineral companies see their opportunities, in Western Australia in particular. The hot briquette plant for BHP that I mentioned would not have occurred unless the Western Australian government had embraced the reform process for the gas industry.

Also in this year's budget was some $200,000 for this year and next year for a project on the goldfields pipeline which will encourage investment in that area by looking at the infrastructure needed to bring together not only the governments of Western Australia and the Commonwealth but also companies like Western Mining which are looking at the opportunities that will come from the pipeline that will flow through to Kalgoorlie. Obviously, that is of great benefit to Australia. For example, if the hot briquette program were to go ahead, as I think it will, instead of exporting iron ore at $22 per tonne for iron ore finds, we would get $190 per tonne for iron ore briquettes.
Obviously, this would have a very powerful impact on the current account. Once more, this industry is playing a vital role in Australia's future.
