Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—The Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The damage to Australia's national interest caused by divisions within the government on the resumption of French nuclear testing in the Pacific.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst there are obviously deep and very bitter divisions within the Labor Party over the government's weak response to the issue of French nuclear tests, there are not divisions in the Australian community about Labor's attitude. First, 95 per cent of Australians are opposed to the resumption of French nuclear testing but, secondly, the overwhelming majority of Australians believes that this government's response to the French has been weak, ineffectual and vacillating.

PARA.TAB: As you go around the Australian community, one of the things you find is that Australians are overwhelmingly ashamed of their government for not showing strength when strength of government really matters; that is, standing up for the national interest in international affairs. This government's response will go down in history as one of the truly weak actions in Australian foreign policy.

When, finally, last Friday the government decided that it would come up with a package of different measures, which were announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) after a cabinet meeting that we read all about in the weekend newspapers, all the government was basically doing was playing follow-the-leader.

Members on our side will remember only too well that last week, as a result of a coalition initiative, the Prime Minister decided he would come into the House and move a motion condemning the French for resuming nuclear tests. Members on the other side may not remember that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) moved an amendment to that motion with four different proposals in it. Each of those proposals, interestingly enough, by Friday had been picked up by the government and the government was running around saying, `Look how strong we've been.' I notice the Prime Minister in his press release used the word `strong' a dozen or so times to try to make the point. You always have to be suspicious of people who do that. Bob Hawke when he was Prime Minister always used to say that he was honest. Why did he always feel it was necessary to tell people he was honest? Because he knew we did not assume he was. This Prime Minister goes on and on about how strong he is. `I am strong,' he says, `and here is my strong response,' which basically incorporated the four different proposals that the coalition put in its amendment.

But the Labor Party had voted against those proposals. Never forget that, when the coalition said on Tuesday that Australia should suspend defence ties with France, you people over there voted against it. On Tuesday you were not in favour of suspending defence ties with France—but by Friday the heat of the kitchen made you change. That is playing follow-the-leader. That is not being strong; that is being weak and vacillating. For you to vote against a whole series of measures and then subsequently incorporate them is pathetic hypocrisy.

No wonder the public are ashamed of their government. What we found out today says a great deal about the Labor Party and the way it handled this issue. We know that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), Senator Ray and Senator Evans all wanted to make a weak response on this issue. They always had wanted to take a soft line. What we have discovered today is that one of the measures that the government suddenly decided to implement—that is, the return of the Australian ambassador in Paris for consultations—was already planned. We have discovered that the ambassador had already planned to return here on leave. The French government had already been told by the ambassador that he was coming back on leave. Senator Evans and the Prime Minister put out a press release saying that one of their tough measures against the French was that the ambassador was going to come back here on leave for consultations. The ambassador had planned about two months ago to speak to the Australian Business in Europe Forum this Thursday in Sydney. He was always coming back. How seriously can you take the latest bout of measures?

We have also discovered, since the government has said that there will be no defence procurement initiatives as far as the French are concerned, that the government had no intention of making a decision to buy French defence equipment over the next nine to 12 months—absolutely no intention at all.

Talking of divisions in the Labor Party, the government, let us face it, has rejected a large number of the proposals put forward by the Left. I dug out the press release that the Left put out the night Brian Howe said he was retiring as Deputy Prime Minister. There were 10 different demands by the Left. They are in the press release which described President Chirac as `a captive of the French military-industrial complex'—that old, charming language of the 1950s. When you go through the press release and look at the 10 proposals, what the government has agreed to is three of the 10 proposals. Three out of 10 is the score that the Left must give the government for its response on nuclear testing. Then we have the members sitting at the back, the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) and the member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth). I think the member for Moreton was the member who had a doorstop press conference today and certainly members of the Left—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—Right and Left.
—You two did. At lunchtime you were out there savaging the government over the issue of uranium sales to France.
—You weren't there; you don't know what I said.

—One of my staff was, I am sorry to tell you. You were asked whether you agreed with the view of the Prime Minister and Senator Evans that uranium sales to France would have to continue. Their view is a perfectly rational view, oddly enough, on this occasion. You are two people who said it was an absolute disgrace and that you totally disagreed with it. The Left of the Labor Party, of course, is a pitiful and weak creature. You got three out of 10 and ran around the press gallery and out into the community saying you are satisfied. Three out of 10 is good enough for the Left. No wonder the Right has been rolling the Left for years.

PARA.TAB: The more serious issue is the leaking from the cabinet. There is no better sign that a government is falling apart than leaking from the cabinet. That is the sign that, as ministers flick through the fortnightly opinion polls, they think the game is up. After all their stunts and initiatives, they have not caught the imagination of the public.
Mr Knott interjecting—

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable members for Gilmore and Gippsland!

PARA.TAB: All this basically does is underline the deep divisions, the deep splits, there are in the government on this important issue. What sort of message does that send to the French? I imagine that the French ambassador over in his residence, in his chancery, is chuckling away as he looks at the divisions within the government, the leaks coming out of the cabinet and at members of the caucus hacking away at each other over the issue of a resumption of French nuclear testing.

I suppose the real point here is: what is the source of all these divisions? As usual, the fount of all evil in this government is the Prime Minister himself. What Senator Evans has done—at least a source close to Senator Evans, such as his mouth—in this article in the Australian is effectively say that the Prime Minister argued that Australia should take a soft and weak position. We have discovered from talking to people in the bureaucracy that that letter reveals the weak position this government always planned to take on a resumption of French nuclear testing.

That letter is a weak letter. That letter concedes the point. That letter was basically a wink and a nudge to President Chirac saying that politically we will have to protest but deep down inside we do not care too much.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your record?

The response from the rest of the Labor Party has been to leak information and to hack away at each other. In your particular case, you probably have not even noticed the issue has been going on because you have been going around attacking councillors in your electorate.

Australia's national interest has been compromised because we do not have a government that has the political strength to stand up for the national interest in international affairs. PARA.TAB: I think it is important that we show people in the gallery and around Australia the record of the opposition on this matter. She asked the minister:

SPEECH.PARA: Did his Department receive information confirming that a nuclear device was detonated at Muroroa Atoll on 9 December 1980. If so, did the Government lodge any protest with the French Ambassador; if not, why not?
The former minister for foreign affairs in the last Liberal government—he is now not even a member of parliament—Mr Street, answered:
(1) I have reason to believe that France conducted further underground nuclear tests at Muroroa Atoll in the South Pacific in the period late November to early December.

PARA.TAB: I would like to see a few opposition members show me where they have walked up and down Bourke Street. SPEECH.PARA: In relation to these amendments, and for the record, I will briefly put a number of matters before the House. The government is moving amendment No. 1 because it does not support the coalition's proposal which would allow the tourism industry to claim free samples. The government is concerned that the cost of this coalition proposal would be between $5 million and $10 million per annum.

PARA.TAB: We also want to place on record that no industry sector is allowed to claim free samples given away in Australia, and to allow this amendment would be to give preferential treatment to the tourism industry over other industry sectors. The Australian Tourist Commission already funds these types of promotional visits which are, in any event, felt to be in the national tourism industry's interest. The government has some very serious concerns about the accountability of free samples for this industry sector.

Government amendment No. 2 relates to the coalition's amendment which would allow the tourism industry access to joint venture facilities. The government opposes that amendment and is moving to withdraw the provision on the following grounds. The cost is estimated to be initially $2 million to $3 million which, on the scale of the Commonwealth's budget, may be relatively small but there is a very real concern that the cost may escalate quickly. Furthermore, large tourism operators currently excluded because of the $25 million export earnings upper limit would be able to gain access to the scheme through this facility. The scheme would also promote a number of developments which may not otherwise occur. Fundamentally, tourism operates through joint promotion anyway and the existing provisions of the act encourage this.

It should also be stressed that the aggregation of three or more tourism amenities would qualify the group for the 50 per cent grant rate, thereby providing a means of circumventing the application of the 25 per cent rate to single-service providers. Finally, because inbound tour operators operate largely on a joint basis with providers there is the potential, under the current rules, for them to receive multiple grants for joint ventures for different components of the same promotion.

Amendment No. 3 relates to the insertion of new section 21A. It is in response to the Democrats' and coalition amendment to the Export Market Development Grant Amendment Bill in the Senate which provides for a 50 per cent grant to single-service tourism providers. The government is opposed to the initiative of the coalition and the Democrats in this matter and will move to reinstate the 25 per cent grant rate provided for in the bill as originally introduced in the Senate.

The cost of this amendment is estimated to be $5 million in 1995-96, $7.5 million in 1996-97, $9 million in 1997-98 and $9 million 1998-99. This places a very heavy onus on the coalition to justify these expenditure proposals. Very vociferous arguments are often put by the coalition in this regard. The government would say that they are often mindless arguments for cost cutting. This is an example of a significant increased cost. Again, the coalition says one thing and then says something very different in relation to the matter before the House.

The government's approach to this matter is based on the findings of EMDG-ITES evaluation which included independent analysis by Price Waterhouse, Professor Ron Bewley, the head of the economics department of the University of New South Wales, and the Allen Consulting Group. The evaluation found that a portion of the tourism industry promotion did not create additional tourism and that it directed tourists who were already coming to Australia to particular facilities. This is the captive market consideration.

The evaluation also found that there was a very strong interrelationship between individual promotion and generic promotion. It is a matter of record that the government already provides significant support for generic promotion through the Australian Tourist Commission. Given these considerations, the government considers that the 25 per cent rate gives fair and balanced access for the tourism industry. These matters have been the subject of very serious consideration within the government and they deserve the support of the House.

The bill implements a number of initiatives announced in the 1995 budget that respond not only to the particular needs that families have at certain times but also to the need of families to deal with a simpler and more consistent system.

A maternity allowance will be introduced from 1 February 1996. The allowance, equal to six times the maximum weekly rate of parenting allowance—that is, $816 at current rates—will be paid for each child born on or after 1 February 1996. It will be paid irrespective of whether the mother is in or outside the paid work force prior to the child's birth. The maternity allowance recognises that the majority of women in the work force are not entitled to paid maternity leave and, at the same time, recognises the extra financial burden placed on all families following the birth of a child. It represents a further significant enhancement of the social wage by this government.

Maternity allowance will also be paid for new-born adopted children, stillborn children and for children who die soon after birth. All families who meet the family payment residency and income and assets tests will qualify for maternity allowance. It is estimated that maternity allowance will be paid for some 223,000 children each year—that is, about 85 per cent of children born each year.

A single family payment will replace the existing basic family payment and additional family payment from 1 January 1996. This change recognises the fact that the different rate structures for basic family payment and additional family payment make it difficult for families to work out their entitlements. A further change will mean that family payment will be payable to whichever member of a couple is the primary carer of a family's child or children. This change will remove the existing gender bias.

Family payment will have three rates, depending only on the age of the child. The maximum fortnightly rates, to be indexed on 1 January 1996, are $88.90 for a child under 13; $115.80 for a child aged 13 to 15; and $55.70 for a student child aged 16 to 18. The minimum fortnightly rate, which will be indexed on 1 January each year, will be $21.70 for each child.

A large family supplement will be paid to families with four or more children at a fortnightly rate of $7.20 for the fourth and each subsequent child. Under the family payment income test, every dollar of income over the free area will reduce entitlement by 50c per year. Families whose income would reduce their payment below the minimum will still be paid the minimum rate, provided their income is below the income ceiling. This ceiling, to be indexed annually, is equivalent to the current basic family income test limit of $61,020 plus $3,051 for the second and each subsequent child. The minimum rate may also be paid under other special circumstances, such as hardship and temporary absence from Australia.

Family payment will continue to be subject to an assets test. Families with assets between $376,750 and $559,250—these amounts will be indexed annually—will be limited to the minimum rate. Families with assets over this limit may qualify for family payment under special provisions. A maintenance income test will also apply to family payment but will not reduce the rate to below the minimum rate of family payment.

The income and assets free areas for family payment and Austudy will be aligned at 1 January 1996 and indexed according to changes in the CPI in January each year. Student dependency limits will be set at the Austudy 18-year-old `away from home' rate and measured over a financial year—and, for social security purposes, the age of dependency of students will be aligned to the Austudy age of 22 years.

In the past, some families have expressed great concern that they have not been able to have their family payment reassessed when they have a change in family circumstances because their incomes have fallen by less than 25 per cent. The bill addresses this problem by making family payment more responsive to the needs of families facing a drop in income. From 1 January 1996 any family who has a fall in their income will be able to apply to have their family payment based on an estimate of their income in the current financial year, rather than the previous financial year, regardless of the size of the reduction in income. This will mean that families will be able to receive additional benefits at the time they need them most. They will not have to wait until the next annual assessment to have their family payment increased. This improvement to the responsiveness of the system will benefit over 62,000 families.

Under the previous rules, families who needed to advise the Department of Social Security of a change in circumstances and whose incomes increased by less than 25 per cent were not obliged to have their family payments reviewed and were allowed to keep the extra payments for the rest of the year as windfall gains. Under the new rules to be implemented from 1 January 1996, families who have a notifiable change in circumstances and whose incomes increase will have their family payment reassessed if their estimated income is 10 per cent higher than their base tax year income and 10 per cent above their income free limit.

Families will be able to amend their income estimates whenever and as often as they choose and will be allowed a 10 per cent margin for error on family payment income estimates. Only families whose actual income is at least 110 per cent of their estimated income will incur an overpayment. This will avoid the need to raise and recover smaller family payment overpayments.

As the Prime Minister further noted in An agenda for families, `families change in character and shape with the changing times, but their essential roles remain the same. Good policy is both responsive to change and consistent with the unchanging roles and needs of families.' That is the guiding philosophy of the government's agenda for families, for the measures included in this bill and for a number of other measures relating to families that will be included in social security bills to be introduced later this year. I commend the bill to the House.

PARA.TAB: The introduction of the family allowance, or, if you like, the reintroduction of the maternity allowance—after it was abolished by the previous government under the then Treasurer, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard)—is an important occasion in the life of this parliament, and an important occasion in the lives of Australian families, given that the parents of some 223,000 children born per year, or 85 per cent of those giving birth, will be eligible for the payment. The amendments relating to the amalgamation of basic family payments, additional family payments, the alignment with Austudy and to the change in the responsiveness to increases and decreases in income are all quite relevant and coherent. They very much reinforce the rationale of the social wage notion that we as a government have pursued since March 1983. That did not come up last week or last month; it has been at the forefront of policy making since before 1983—before we were in government. We came into government promising things such as Medicare so we could look after the two million people who then were not insured. Throughout our time in government, it has been at the forefront of policy making.

The member for Moreton raised a few matters, and I wish to add to those. Look at issues like TEAS, the old tertiary education assistance scheme. It was introduced by the previous Labor government and left to languish as a result of neglect and decay in the Fraser era. It became way out of kilter with unemployment benefits and of course way out of kilter with family needs. The development of that scheme into Austudy and its extension to include eligibility for high school students in years 11 and 12 has had a massive effect on Australian families. In 1983 one in three school pupils stayed beyond year 10 at school. That was the norm for Australia under conservative governments. It is now something like four out five. Changes to and the enhancement of Austudy have been fundamental in that area.

As I said, one has to remember the old TEAS arrangements and also measures such as the rental allowance. In March 1983 the rental allowance was available to only people on pensions. It was $5 a week. But, for every dollar of non-pension income, pensioners lost 50c of that allowance. Once they began earning $10 a week from investments, super or anything else, the rent allowance was gone. So it applied to very few people. As I said, it was $5 a week 12 years ago.

The member for Moreton referred to the increase in child-care places and there being some four or five times as many. It is indicative. Think also about the age pension. In 1975, when the previous Labor government was dismissed from office, the age pension was running at almost 26 per cent of average weekly earnings. In March 1983 it was down to 21 1/2 per cent. Seven years of conservative government dropped it by about 20 per cent or a little more. Now it is back to almost 26 per cent. That is just an indication.

I can recall so well the system we inherited, because of the problems I had as a member representing my constituents. I was informed of pensioners paying tax on earnings above $3 a week. At one stage in the mid-1980s, people paid tax on anything over that. The confusion and chaos that caused for our older people was massive. Now there is a tax-free zone of $47 a week per single pensioner. One would not recognise the system. That is all part of the social wage, and it is about families. In those days many Australian workers supported aged members of their family because the government did not support them well enough. That does not happen as much any more.

I recall that one of my constituents, a pensioner, was paying $40 of his pension towards the cost of his wife staying in a nursing home. He lived on dog food and cat food. For eight years he paid $40 from his pension every week for his wife to stay in a nursing home—and we get nonsense from those opposite about poverty and about how caring they are. The rent allowance; Austudy; retention rates at school; Medicare, which has been touched on; child care; pensions; and the taxation rate—as mentioned yesterday by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and today by the Treasurer (Mr Willis), we dealt with tax rates of 60 per cent at the top margin and 30 per cent at the bottom; in fact, in 1983 the lowest tax people paid was 30c in the dollar, and now it is 20c—are all aspects which affect families.

If we were to ask many of the people who have been forced into accepting the social wage, I think we would find they would rather not be dependent and would rather take care of their own affairs. A report has recently been done on poverty in Queensland, my home state. Many families in Queensland have also been affected by the federal government's failure to deal with the family policy. Queensland has the lowest average weekly disposable income. Sole parent families, couples with three or more children and young single people have the greatest chance of being in poverty. One fifth, or 20 per cent, of the Queensland population now lives in poverty. Some 18 per cent, or 350,000 Queenslanders, live below the poverty line. TALK.START.PARA: —I get a bit carried away sometimes. The government has to respond to that report on poverty in Queensland. It is a damning indictment of this government. But by idealising the father archetype at the expense of the mother archetype, old-guard feminists have compounded the devaluation of women and motherhood, and have deprived women of choice.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole direction in which family policy has gone is essentially flawed. The roles of men and women are not interchangeable. One only has to visit a labour ward in a hospital to realise this, and no amount of affirmative action will change that. What we have had is crude social engineering by this government over many years. We have a system in place now where wives under 40 whose husbands are unemployed do not get a partner allowance. This government has been very good over the years at tokenism, and this is another example of that. The maternity allowance, along with many of these other handouts to families, will be funded out of tax increases which ironically make it more difficult for the average young father to support his wife and baby at a time when that financial support is most needed.

The government's social engineering has brought about this redistribution of income: it goes to the tax office and the social security department and then it ultimately goes back to the place where it came from in the first place, except it is in the form of welfare. I can only assume that that circuitous route, which is driven by a social engineering agenda, is absolutely intentional. If the government wanted to break down and damage families over the 12 years that it has been in office, then it can certainly claim to have succeeded.

Most of them do not want it. But the fact is that they have been forced into accepting it in one form or another. It will take a very long time—perhaps a generation—to reverse all of that and bring about a situation where families are once again left in peace.

People have been forced onto welfare via the so-called social wage. Some 76 per cent of all unemployed are men, many of whom have been destroyed by that experience of unemployment. They are unable to provide for their families because the government steps in and does it for them. But what effect does this have on those men and their morale? What effect does it have on their natural inclination to want to care for their families—their wives and their children? It has a devastating effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Chuck them off.
—If you think it is funny, you should talk to some of them and let them tell you about their problems.

B.'—noted that he had spoken to Mr Brian Smith from the Australian Government Solicitor's Office in Sydney, which was handling the Commonwealth's defence. The document reads:

TALK.START.PARA: —The remarks I make tonight, I am sure, will not be quite as exciting as some of the remarks made by the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) or those members who went before him, but they are somewhat more important to the future of this country and to those people who pay mortgages. I would like to draw the attention of the House to a country that has not been mentioned as often as Mexico and France have been this week—that is, Japan. I would also like to refer to the situation that is occurring with the banking and financial sector in that country.

PARA.TAB: What has been reported in the Australian media about the troubles in the balance sheets of the banks in Japan, in particular the city banks, really understates the position. In the last couple of days we have seen our dollar grow weaker on speculation of trouble in the Senate. This illustrates the fact that this week many foreign investors are less willing again to risk their wealth in Australia. It illustrates to me our vulnerability to rises in interest rates and trouble in foreign bond markets.

I have seen the trouble looming in Japan. As I said, the situation in the banks in Japan is worse than has been reported. In the case of some Japanese banks, their capital is now exceeded by the amount of their non-performing loans, less the reserves that they have set aside for those loans, thus rendering them technically insolvent. This is the case with at least three of the large banks there. Further, four of the eight large housing loan companies in Japan are already technically insolvent and, in one case, a rescue has been undertaken by the ministry of finance.

If we estimate Japan's total GNP at around Y475 trillion, the total non-performing loans of the financial sector is estimated at about Y60 trillion to Y80 trillion, which puts it at around 15 per cent of GNP. This is extraordinarily high. The figure for the worst period of the savings and loan crisis in the United States in the early 1990s was around eight or nine per cent. Yet in Japan, our biggest trading partner and possibly the largest holder of Australian bonds, that figure has reached 15 per cent.

In a climate where the profitability of these banks is looking rather poor, to say the least—given the troubles with the earthquake in Kobe, the troubles with the religious sect, Aum Shinri Kyo, and the trade dispute with the United States about cars—you could say it is hardly likely that the banks' operating profits will improve in the next cycle. Therefore, the likelihood of serious difficulty with one of Japan's major banks is much greater than it was perhaps at any time in the last 20 years. It is quite plain that the banks' balance sheets are deteriorating quickly.

Furthermore, many Japanese banks—unlike Australian or American banks—have large holdings of Japanese shares. They traditionally take a two or three per cent stake in any of their larger customers which are listed on the stock exchange, although they are limited to a five per cent stake. What it has meant is that their capital is devoted to equities to a much greater extent than it is anywhere else in the world.

The Japanese stock index—the Nikkei 225—is now sitting at about 15,000. Given the very low return on equity and the fact that dividend yields are less than one per cent, you could fairly say that that index is still overvalued at 15,000. Yet these banks still hold large amounts of these equities in their customers. If it is overvalued at 15,000 and if fair value is perhaps 9,000 or 10,000 on that index, if that share market were to reach fair value it would render insolvent many of the smaller banks—especially the regional banks—which in turn would send a shock wave through the bond market, first of all in Japan. The likely consequences of that would be that the banks which hold Australian bonds and US dollar bonds would be forced to sell them and repatriate the capital back to Japan to shore up their balance sheets.

I would like to draw the House's attention to this matter because it has not been properly reported in our financial media. Given that we are looking at possibly a record current account deficit of between $2.5 billion and $2.7 billion for May—which will be announced on Friday—we are more vulnerable than ever before.

ANSWER.PARA: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

PARA.TAB: The relationship between CSIRO and Gerard Cassegrain & Co Pty Limited ("GC&Co") began in 1987, initially on a quite limited basis with a view to developing an improved machine for soil amelioration. The relationship later became directed principally towards the further development of two technologies originating within CSIRO, soil slotting and sewage disposal by means of vertical upflow artificial wetlands. Neither technology proved able, in practice, to generate a sufficient revenue flow during the course of the relationship. In the early stages both parties entertained very optimistic expectations as to prospects. Later, there was disagreement over the size of respective contributions, responsibilities for further funding, and the interpretation of the various agreements and understandings. Ultimately, the disagreements crystallised around the question whether the joint relationship for developing the two technologies should continue.

Court proceedings concerning the disputes were instituted in 1992, and a lengthy Federal Court hearing began on 26 October 1992, which continued, with interruptions, until 2 July 1993. The hearing was never finished and the Court did not reach conclusions on the matter.

After a mediation before Sir Laurence Street, an accommodation was reached to enable termination of the proceedings, ending of the relationship, and transfer of the technologies to CSIRO, on the basis that this was not to be taken as reflecting in any way adversely on GC&Co and Mr Cassegrain. Their contribution to the development of the two technologies was acknowledged. The confidentiality provisions that were agreed limited further public statements to the parties on the subject of the disputes, while acknowledging CSIRO's accountability obligations.

Aspects of the questions asked appear based on assumptions as to the legal relationship between GC&Co and CSIRO and the resulting disputes. The nature and extent of the legal relationship between GC&Co and CSIRO was the subject of the dispute explored, but not resolved, in the course of the Federal Court proceedings. No conclusions were reached by the Court on this aspect, nor was the collection of all evidence relevant to the disputes ever completed. Following the mediation before Sir Laurence Street, the parties conducted an extensive negotiation to document the accommodation reached. The parties to the Deed of Settlement and Release completed on 27 September 1993 between GC&Co, Mr Claude Cassegrain and CSIRO and Sirotech Limited ("Sirotech") (the "Settlement Deed") agreed, without admission of liability by any of them, to resolve all disputes between them that were or could become the subject of the Federal Court proceedings, together with all other disputes that had arisen or might arise, directly or indirectly, from or otherwise in connection with, any dealing, occurrence, transaction or representation between them occurring prior to completion of the settlement on 27 September 1993.

In some areas, a common position was reached in the course of documenting the Settlement Deed. In other areas, the parties, in effect, agreed to differ, and reached a practical resolution which did not involve any conclusion as to the underlying disputes that had previously existed. The Settlement Deed released all claims between the parties in respect of any dealing, occurrence, transaction or representation occurring prior to 27 September 1993 and included covenants by the parties that they would not initiate or continue any claim or demand in respect of the matters the subject of the releases, would not encourage or assist any other party to do so, and would use their best endeavours to procure that their Associates did not do so. The Settlement Deed was entered into with a view to avoiding any occasion for further issues between the parties to the settlement relating to the prior disputes or prior areas of potential dispute. This introduction explains the general nature of the issues that emerged and the manner in which the Organisation has addressed the need to ensure that these issues do not recur. As the parties have resolved the resulting disputes and many cannot be examined without comments on the position of individuals in areas where the inquiries associated with the Court proceedings were not completed, it is not considered useful or desirable to explore the details of the many allegations made during the Court proceedings.

Many of the questions relate to specific claims and allegations made by GC&Co in proceedings G3062 and G3095 in the Federal Court. The hearing of the proceedings continued for many months but conclusions resolving these matters were not reached by the Court or, in most cases, in the Settlement Deed. It was agreed in the Settlement Deed to resolve the disputes without admission of liability and without reaching any specific factual conclusions as to most of the disputes.

Many of the questions contain imputations as to the motives and purposes of CSIRO or Sirotech personnel, which cannot fairly be answered comprehensively, having regard to the termination of the Court proceedings. To compile all the relevant material on many of these specific issues, it would be necessary to devote very large resources to analyse the court transcript and the many relevant documents. Any individuals upon whom there was adverse reflection would need, as a matter of fairness, to be given an opportunity to state their position. Essentially, the Organisation would be taking on the role of a Court in trying to determine the facts.

In dealing with these issues, CSIRO encountered problems to which it had never previously been exposed. The written agreements between the parties did not provide a clear and detailed guidance as to their respective rights and obligations in the situation that had developed by 1991. In some respects the relationship had developed apart from the written agreements and the identification of relevant intellectual property was inadequate or misunderstood. In key areas, there was no provision for resolution of disputes and there were factual and legal difficulties in quantifying contributions that had been made and further contribution obligations.

The early accounts of the disputes between CSIRO, Sirotech and GC&Co that were given to senior management and CSIRO's legal advisers by the personnel directly involved in the relationship appeared to indicate that CSIRO and Sirotech representatives had tried, for some time after the difficulties arose, to make the relationship work. Only after many months of Court proceedings and additional disclosures of large volumes of documents did a picture emerge that indicated that, in some respects, some CSIRO and Sirotech personnel had not, looking at the overall situation, displayed the standards of judgement and conduct to which the Organisation aspires.

When this became clear, the CSIRO Board established a sub-committee and the sub-committee and senior management devoted substantial time and effort to developing an appropriate response, and resolving the dispute. By that time, the hearing of the Court proceedings had already continued for some eight months (with interruptions) at massive cost to all concerned. The cross-examination of each individual witness often took many weeks and many allegations were made during cross-examination. As the evidence stood at that time, there was support for some, but not all, of these allegations. Whether this would have remained the situation at the conclusion of the hearing is impossible to say. Some of the main witnesses remained to be called, and others needed to be recalled. Continuation of the Court proceedings would also have necessitated further detailed inquiries within the Organisation and the compilation of additional evidence to explain and amplify some of the matters that had emerged during cross-examination. Mediation before Sir Laurence Street and the negotiation of over two months which led to the Settlement Deed offered an alternative to this.

Before and after the settlement was reached, senior management examined what had occurred and considered appropriate responses. The mediation and Settlement Deed identified a monetary sum of $9.5 million agreed to by GC&Co, Mr Cassegrain, CSIRO and Sirotech in comprehensive discharge of all claims and rights in respect of the relevant technologies and all claims relating to all the allegations made in the Court proceedings and associated costs.

This case clearly demonstrated CSIRO's inexperience in commercial dealings at this time. Numerous shortcomings and gaps in the way CSIRO approached commercialisation of its research in the 1987—1989 period were identified. CSIRO has learnt many valuable lessons from this case and, most importantly, has transferred the knowledge and experience gained into the development of a Commercial Practice Manual, a working document for use by all CSIRO staff with responsibilities for commercial activities.

The Commercial Practice Manual is a working guide which provides CSIRO staff with the Organisation's policies and practices for commercial dealings, practical examples of how particular matters are handled and the standards expected of CSIRO staff involved in commercial activities.

The Commercial Practice Manual was implemented in February 1994. Some 500 research and other senior staff with responsibilities for commercial activities were provided with information on the contents of the Manual and its use through a series of Workshops run by the Chief Executive and Executive Committee supported by presentations from experienced commercial and legal personnel. Since that time the Manual has been introduced to staff through similar Workshops held in CSIRO Divisions.

The Commercial Practice Manual is not a panacea. However it does ensure that staff are now equipped with (1) practical up-to-date knowledge, (2) direct access to necessary tools, (3) an understanding of the behavioural standards required and (4) clearly identified CSIRO practices which, if followed, will prevent the recurrence of difficulties of this nature.
CSIRO considers that the case demonstrated that:

there is a risk of great ill-feeling and significant financial exposure if a commercial relationship is embarked upon, without prior detailed documentation of the rights and obligations of the parties in unambiguous terms;

some scientists had failed, during the formation and conduct of the relationship with GC&Co, sufficiently to appreciate that commercial parties have a view to financial return and do not regard research as an end in itself; and

in the absence of specific contractual provisions to resolve disputes and provide for termination of a relationship in relevant circumstances, disputes can prove both difficult and expensive to resolve, particularly having regard to the complexities of the fact-finding process through the Courts.
More specifically it appears that:
(a) the procedures in place within CSIRO during the 1987 to 1989 period had given scientists a role in negotiations and the conduct of commercial relationships for which they were not equipped;

(b) some of the specialist personnel within Sirotech had not during that period adequately explained the difficulties that could arise from the approach to documenting the relationship with GC&Co that was adopted, and had not provided adequate advice and guidance as to the manner in which the relationship should be documented and administered;

(c) aspects of the misunderstandings arose from the use in agreements of vague and general concepts or very wide intellectual property definitions, compounded by the informality in the conduct of the relationship which characterised its earlier period—both of which aspects had occurred with the concurrence of both parties to this relationship;

Senior management concluded that the inadequacies of the approach to documenting the relationship had played a key role in causing the dispute and associated earlier and later misunderstandings. Earlier structural problems in terms of changing personnel, too much involvement of scientists in negotiations and poor communication between Sirotech personnel and the scientists appeared substantially to blame.

Many of the later disputes were extremely complicated, and the different individual participants in the disputes made conflicting submissions as to the motives and purposes of those involved. Some of the different perceptions were explicable in terms of misunderstandings as to the legal issues and legal obligations of the parties, having regard to the deficiencies in the earlier approach to documenting the relationship. Senior management did not exhaustively investigate all the circumstances surrounding the various inadequacies identified but informed itself sufficiently to form the view that they may well have been occasioned by honest misunderstanding rather than deliberate misconduct. Senior management was concerned at the ignorance and misunderstandings that had occurred in relation to the obligation to produce documents for the purposes of the court proceedings, drew to the attention of all those involved its concern at the inadequate approach adopted, and resolved, in any future litigation, to ensure that more satisfactory procedures and approaches were adopted.

Without continuation of the Court proceedings, or recourse to some equally authoritative fact-finding tribunal, such matters could not be authoritatively resolved. Large expense and disruption to continuing research would have been occasioned by a sufficiently detailed inquiry into individual culpability associated with the problems identified. It appeared that the costs and expenses of further inquiry into those matters would be disproportionate to any additional lessons that might be learnt for the future. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 29 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What programs does his Department provide to assist persons registered as unemployed with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) and in receipt of social security benefits to establish their own businesses.
(2) What (a) conditions and means tests apply and (b) services and payments are available under each program.

(3) Under the programs, does his Department assist a successful applicant with (a) rent of business premises, (b) plant, (c) licensing, (d) other general start up costs and (e) employment and payment of staff if the business expands.

(4) Under the programs, does his Department (a) consider the potential for success of proposed new businesses it supports, (b) assist with the preparation of business plans or (c) consider the impact on existing businesses and the market.
(5) Does his Department provide assistance to unemployed persons not registered as unemployed with the CES nor in receipt of social security benefits to establish their own businesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Employment Education and Training (DEET) administers a labour market program called the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS) which assists eligible unemployed people to establish new and commercially viable businesses.
(2)(a) There are participant and business eligibility criteria to be met in order to receive NEIS assistance.
The eligibility criteria are that participants must:
be unemployed and registered for full-time work with the CES;
be over 18 years of age and less than age pension age while receiving NEIS Allowance;
be in receipt of, or dependant on, DSS income support that includes a living allowance component;
be available to participate in NEIS business skills training (unless the Managing Agent believes training is not necessary and obtains exemption from training);
be available to work full-time in the business for the period of NEIS Allowance (ie at least 20 hours each week);
not be an undischarged bankrupt; and
not have received NEIS assistance in the previous 6 months or previously for the same business activity.
The business eligibility criteria are that the proposed business must:
be new and not yet operating on a full-time basis;
be independent and reputable;

be assessed as commercially viable by a NEIS Advisory Committee; and not compete directly with existing businesses unless it can be demonstrated that there is an unsatisfied demand for the product or service, or the goods or services are to be provided in a new way.

Acceptance for a NEIS training course does not guarantee that the person will receive NEIS Allowance. NEIS Allowance is provided to clients only if the NEIS Advisory Committee informs DEET that the business is expected to be commercially viable within 52 weeks of program assistance.

The payment of NEIS Allowance is income tested against an income threshold of average weekly earnings. Income for the purposes of the income test includes net profit before tax (adjusted for capital purchases) and any non-NEIS business income of the NEIS participant as well as spouse income (excluding NEIS Allowance and DSS Income Support).
(b) NEIS assistance to the jobseeker consists of:
training in small business skills and small business management;
Formal Training Allowance while undertaking training;
NEIS Allowance for up to 52 weeks equivalent to the basic adult rate of Job Search Allowance; and
mentor support for the first year of business operation.
Other NEIS payments include:
a fee to Managing Agents for jobseekers who are approved for NEIS Allowance and commence their NEIS businesses; and
a fee to Managing Agents to pay for mentor services of up to $300 per NEIS business.

DEET does not provide assistance to NEIS participants for start-up capital costs. However, some State/Territory Governments provide loans or grants to eligible NEIS participants. Currently the Queensland Government provides interest-free loans of up to $6,000 per participant. The Northern Territory Government provides interest-free loans of $3,000 to a single participant or $6,000 to partnered participants. The ACT Government provides a grant of up to $4,000 per NEIS business.

(e) NEIS businesses may be able to receive JobStart subsidies for employees. JobStart is a wage subsidy program administered by the CES that provides access to employment for jobseekers who have experienced long periods of unemployment or face other disadvantages in obtaining work. Under the program, employers receive subsidy payments for a set period of up to 39 weeks as an incentive to employ disadvantaged job seekers. The JobStart subsidies are available for most full-time and permanent part-time and casual jobs offering 20 hours a week or over. Businesses must be able to meet the requirements of the JobStart Subsidy Agreement including the provision of three months ongoing employment at the end of the subsidy period.

Assistance may also be available to NEIS businesses taking on trainees. Traineeships are provided to boost the level of training and work opportunities available to young people, adults and the long term unemployed. Under Traineeships, jobseekers are employed as trainees and are provided with an approved combination of training and work and are paid a training wage. On completion of their traineeship, trainees receive an industry recognised certificate. Under Traineeships, employers who take on a trainee may receive subsidies ranging from $2,000 to $12,640 depending on the trainees' level of labour market disadvantage.

(4)(a) The Department considers the potential for success of proposed new businesses it supports through NEIS. In order to receive NEIS assistance the business must be assessed as commercially viable by a NEIS Advisory Committee.
(b) As part of NEIS training Managing Agents assist clients to develop a business plan which is then submitted to a NEIS Advisory Committee for assessment of commercial viability.

(c) The NEIS guidelines clearly state that proposed NEIS businesses must not compete directly with existing businesses unless it can be demonstrated that there is an unsatisfied demand for the product or service, or the product or service is to be provided in a new way. This aspect must be demonstrated in the NEIS business plans and the NEIS Advisory Committee is careful to assess the impact of proposed NEIS businesses on existing businesses during the selection and approval process.

(5) People who are unemployed but not registered with the CES or in receipt of a social security allowance are not eligible for NEIS. NEIS, like other labour market programs, is targeted to assist those who are most in need, particularly the long term unemployed. Unemployed people not registered with the CES or in receipt of a social security allowance can receive assistance from business incubators.

Since 1991, DEET has provided through the Office of Labour Market Adjustment Regional Program about $4 million towards the establishment and support of some fifty business incubators—property developments which accommodate the start-up and early development of new small businesses. They provide work space on flexible terms, back-up services and management support.

DEET's support for business incubators has now been considerably enhanced by the recent Budget announcement of a new Business Incubator Program which will provide $10 million in 1995-96 to local communities for the establishment of new incubators and enhancement of existing ones. The new program helps employed and unemployed people to set up self employment ventures. Business incubators should lead to about 3,750 new job opportunities over three years.
